SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the House insists on disagreeing to amendments Nos 1, 4 to 22, 24 to 27, 29 to 34, 36, 38, 39, 47, 49 and 54 insisted on by the Senate.

I am disappointed that the Senate dealt with this matter in such a perfunctory way earlier this week by criticising the government in general terms and dealing with irrelevant considerations instead of debating the substance of the matters before it. The concentration of the debate in the Senate on the issue of the government purporting to establish a double dissolution trigger by this legislation was both unworthy and inaccurate. It is especially spurious for the shadow Attorney‐General to assert that this is `a cover for a race based election'.

The government has indicated in the past its desire for the streamlining of the way in which government regulations are produced and scrutinised in order to ensure regulations are relevant, workable and effective and that any unnecessary regulatory burden on business and the community is removed. At the same time, the government has modelled the legislation to ensure that the government is able to maintain control of important programs for which it has a responsibility to the community. It has done so by providing minimum exemption from compliance with parts of the legislative package or by exempting parliamentary disallowance of certain limited instruments.

The current restriction by the Senate, preventing exemption from disallowance of quarantine proclamations based on broad based international negotiations, exemplifies the type of approach which can cause significant difficulties in control of government programs. The Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 represents the product of substantial work by an independent statutory body charged with reviewing the administrative law structures of the Commonwealth and the significant input of the numerous parliamentary committee considerations of the bill as it evolved.

One of the most significant issues to come out of the parliamentary consideration by the 1995 Labor chaired House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs was the recommendation that sunsetting of all delegated legislation be provided for. This bill gives effect to that recommendation. Now the opposition is trying to move away from sunsetting, making spurious claims that the provisions allow the government to renege on continuing desirable delegated legislation following its sunsetting. This attack on the bona fides of the executive is both unworthy and ill‐informed. The government will always consider the continued desirability of delegated legislation in an appropriate way and would only remove it should such legislation be unnecessary.

This bill is an important reform package which will result in fundamental changes to the relationship between the executive and the parliament. The government is voluntarily accepting changes which will significantly increase the power of the parliament to scrutinise delegated legislation. The opposition and the minor parties in the Senate now suggest that the government is treating them with contempt because it does not accept amendments passed by the Senate. Nothing could be further from the truth. This bill has gone through a very careful and even tortured process in its development. It is a reasoned and appropriate response by the government, which, as the government of the day, has to make the final call over what is the appropriate balance between executive responsibility and parliamentary scrutiny and acceptance of delegated legislation.

BREAK.PARA: These last minute amendments by Labor and the Democrats would dramatically reduce the legislation's effectiveness. This is not acceptable to the government. It will also not be acceptable to the Australian community.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was interrupted by question time yesterday, I was talking about the Hunter Valley No. 1 dispute. I was reading a letter from a Mrs Lyn McBain, who is the wife of one of the Hunter Valley No. 1 coalminers. I will pick up where I left off. She said:

SPEECH.PARA: My first hand knowledge of these laws Sir, indicate that a company like Rio Tinto can call upon their global resources of $14 billion to bring 420 miners to their knees, but the workers and the union cannot call for the assistance of any other union or identity because it would be seen as a secondary boycott.
I fear that in future companies with global resources will starve workers into accepting lower wages, substandard work conditions and the abolition of safe work practices.

These are not my words; these are the words of a very desperate wife, a very desperate grandmother and mother. Another miner's wife has been writing poetry about the dispute. I was going to read that to the House, but I fear I am going to run out of time. I therefore seek leave to table the poem.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister. As I said yesterday just prior to question time, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is no friend of the coalmining community. His bipartisan support for these large multinational companies, both Rio Tinto and Arco, has been nothing short of disgraceful. Now we see the government supporting Rio Tinto's appeal against Justice Boulton's decision to force the matter to arbitration. It is quite clear that this is not a dispute either the government or Rio Tinto want resolved. This is their opportunity to use the new Workplace Relations Act to break the back of the trade union movement in this country. As I have said, that has been highlighted by the government's support of Rio Tinto's appeal against Justice Boulton's decision.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the message that the Hunter coalminers want to send to the Prime Minister: you are no friend of the coalmining communi ty, and your attempts to portray yourself as such does no credit to you or the office of Prime Minister. As I said yesterday, it was absolutely outrageous and the height of hypocrisy for the Prime Minister to be standing in this chamber, in question time on 18 November, portraying himself as a friend of the coalminer. I recognise that my behaviour on that day was contrary to standing orders. But I will take every opportunity—if that is what it takes, so be it—to defend my coalminers, the coalminers who are being so unfairly treated by Rio Tinto, with the rather unashamed support of this government.

I move on to another issue that arose out of question time. It was the contention of the Minister for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Vaile) that this government is doing so much more than was previously done for roads in this country. Over four years we have had $600 million cut out of the national highways budget. I think the minister is a great bloke and very capable, but I am very concerned about his appointment as the minister for transport. There is a very simple reason for that: for years and years, National Party MPs on the New South Wales north coast have been seeking to have the New England Highway declassified as part of the national highways structure in order for the Pacific Highway to be classified as a national highway. What does that mean? That means the Pacific Highway, once it gains national highway status, attracts national highways funding.

The transport minister is a National Party MP from the New South Wales north coast and, unashamedly, a great supporter for upgrades of the Pacific Highway. I do not have any concern about upgrades of the Pacific Highway; I support them—but not at the expense of the New England Highway, which stretches through my electorate from Beresfield in the south to Quirindi in the north, and not at the expense of other highways. The minister has demonstrated by his open passion for works on the Pacific Highway during question time this week that I should have legitimate concerns about his appointment. I call upon the minister to restore that national highways funding, so that the New England Highway can continue to get the funding it enjoyed under the previous Labor government.

He contributed $33 million to the Belford Bends project in my electorate—money that was withdrawn immediately upon the election of the Howard‐Fischer government. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, I can certainly understand your disappointment with the previous speaker, the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon), particularly since I am aware of the tremendous work that you have done personally throughout your entire time as a member of this House in championing the need to upgrade the Pacific Highway. I have been delighted with the number of projects that have been approved in my own electorate that are not on the Pacific Highway since this government has come to office. Today I want to speak about a matter that has been debated in the House over recent days. In particular, I want to respond to some comments made by the shadow minister for primary industries which were inaccurate. Firstly, I turn to the expenditure through government bodies of either direct taxpayer funding or moneys collected through industry contributions such as levies.

BREAK.PARA: Yesterday the House considered and approved amendments from another place to the Australian Meat and Live‐stock Industry (Repeals and Consequential Provisions) Bill 1997 . Yesterday, in my remarks on behalf of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Anderson), I said that the government was deeply concerned over Labor's effort to remove item 45 from schedule 5—an item providing that, if staff are offered equivalent employment with the new meat producer company and they refuse that offer, they will be deemed to have resigned and not be entitled to redundancy payments.

This item was proposed by the government in order to protect the rights of employees while providing for both an independent decision on equivalence and a right of independent review. It was aimed at protecting industry funds from misallocation. The government reluctantly accepted this amendment to overcome problems of getting this very important package of legislation in place in a timely manner so that existing staff would not face a four-month period of uncertainty.

In his remarks, the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) was cavalier in his approach; cavalier to the point where I cannot leave his claims unaddressed. He said of this legislation that it was `a nippy little industrial relations stunt'. That remark added nothing whatsoever in terms of credibility for his argument. He dug the hole for himself even deeper. He went on to accuse me of playing with words and hung his argument on this challenge:
You find me previous Labor legislation saying that they will be deemed to have resigned.

How many examples does Labor want? Let me give you a couple for starters. Firstly, the expenditure of funds was protected in this way under the Moomba‐Sydney Pipeline Systems Sale Act 1994. Section 32 of the act states:
Subject to subsection (3), the staff member is, for all purposes, taken to have resigned from the staff member's appointment or engagement under the Pipeline Authority Act 1973.

I urge the honourable member for Burke to keep going and read through clauses 4 and 5 of section 32. Perhaps he failed to consider the Repatriation Institutions (Transfer) Act 1992. He should look at part 4, which deals with certain affected employees who are taken to have resigned. Another example is that of the Housing Loans Insurance Corporation (Sale of Assets and Abolition) Act 1990. The honourable member for Burke should have a look at part 15.

Recently in this place the minister for primary industries was forced to refer to some quite extraordinary comments from the honourable member for Burke about his own ambitions. He wanted the thinking and style of John Kerin, the determination and astuteness of Simon Crean and the bonhomie of Bob Collins. The look on the face of the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) had to be seen to be believed when those comments were made.

Ridiculous comments aside, oppositions are charged with at least providing some element of constructive input to debates on matters of important national policy. We know they could not deal with financial matters during their time in government. There is a $10 billion budget deficit legacy attesting to that fact. What is surprising and disappointing is that the opposition is not showing any signs of having learnt very much. It is not prepared to contribute accurate information to debates.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the appropriation bills, I would like to remind the people of this parliament that a little under a year ago the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) rose in this House to give a progress report to the people of Australia. If my memory serves me correctly, it was a very short speech. Twelve months later I was not surprised to see that the Prime Minister did not have the front to even approach the dispatch box to give a similar oration this year—so little has his government been able to achieve and so absolute has its incompetence been.

SPEECH.PARA: The disintegration of the Howard government over the last 12 months has been a sight to behold. I would be lying if I said that it did not give those of us on this side of politics some degree of satisfaction. That said, there is nothing that we or the Australian people enjoy in watching the country drift from crisis to crisis, directionless, because of the terrible mismanagement of the present administration. We are all the losers because of it.

When the current government came to power in 1996, this country stood at the crossroads. Over the previous 13 years Australia had grown in a number of leaps and bounds. We were a more confident country, we were a more competitive country, we were a more outward looking and proud country than we had been in 1983. But we still faced a number of challenges in the new millennium. Continuing that good work, taking Australia in the right direction, was a job requiring firm leadership, resolve and intelligence.

From the Prime Minister and his team we have had none of the above. As a result, not only has this country been left at the crossroads; it seems to me—as it seems to a great many Australians—we are standing in the middle of the road with a semitrailer breathing down our necks. It is an understatement to say that the Australian people are less confident now than they were 12 months ago. In that short period of time we have become divided as a nation, full of discontent and racked with resentment.

The Prime Minister and his government may be able to appreciate how to dangle a carrot in front of the Australian people, they may be able to understand how to tap into the dark subconscious of the Australian people, to divide them with poise and expertise, but they do not have, and nor do I see them developing it in the future, an awareness of the Australian psyche, of what makes us all tick. If they did, we would not have seen the savage cuts they have meted out to some of the most disadvantaged groups in this country over the past 20 months of their reign; we would not have seen this government trying to wring money from the sick and frail elderly and harassing them with mountains of legalities via their ill‐planned nursing home reforms; we would not have seen a Prime Minister so bereft of feeling and goodwill, so hard-hearted, that he could not apologise on behalf of the nation to the legions of Aboriginal children who were stolen from the arms and homes of their parents year after year until the early 1970s.

This is a Prime Minister, remember, who publicly chastises Aboriginal leaders for what he considers to be their intemperate language but who still harbours individuals like the Member for Capricornia (Mr Marek)—our Paul `20 bucks and a packet of Jatz' Marek—in his ranks without so much as a slap on the wrist. If this government had a true understanding of Australians, we would not be watching hopelessly as the same Prime Minister and his senior colleagues hurtle us towards a double dissolution election based on race, either oblivious to or uncaring of the fact that to do so will turn city against country, black against white and Australian against Australian. To do so will leave a gulf between our country men and women which may be unbridgeable for generations. If they did, we would not be seeing teams of cutthroat mercenaries, skilled in the art of warfare, preparing themselves in a secret training camp in faraway Dubai to take over the nation's waterfront. What bloody and terrible confrontation has this government in store for us? Only time will tell.

The fair and the open‐minded members on the government's back bench know the sort of dramatic juncture Australia finds itself at. The Member for Aston (Mr Nugent), the Member for Kingston (Ms Jeanes) and others like them know, as we do, that presently in this country, whatever level of negligible leadership we do have, we are receiving it without a heart and without a soul. It is doing us severe damage, perhaps irretrievable damage, both inside our borders and in the eyes of our international partners. They know that it is no good attempting to get the economic settings right, that it is no good attempting to look after the general mechanics of policy, if you do not govern with a soul and with an ability to make Australians from all walks of life feel that they live in a fair country, in a principled country and in a moral country. Without these things people cannot walk with their heads held high. They certainly are not going to vote for a government that gave them that cross to bear, no matter what sort of economic figures are dangled in front of their noses.

Just a few short weeks ago, the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) made a damning admission to a journalist from the Canberra Times. In answer to the question, `Is this the worst government Australia has ever seen?' the minister replied:
You're expecting an argument with a proposition like that? You won't get one from me.

Just in case the minister is wondering, he will not get an argument from the people of my electorate either. The last 20 months, as most Australians have seen, has been no picnic for the people of Prospect. The Howard government came to power promising to reduce unemployment. The Prime Minister said, `Give me 12 months before you judge me on my record.' Now, 20 months later, Prime Minister, the Fairfield‐Liverpool local government area, which I represent and which covers the majority of my electorate, has one of the highest rates of unemployment in Australia.

The Treasurer (Mr Costello) may crow about the rate of growth that we are finally reaching in this country—growth rates which, incidentally, we had in government two years ago. However, as long as this growth rate fails to translate into an increase in employment for the people of my electorate—and, from the figures we have seen, there seems to be no sign of this happening—very few of them will take solace in any figures the government comes up with.

The Prime Minister's failure to attack unemployment in western Sydney—indeed, his unsurpassed effectiveness in exacerbating it with his massive cuts to employment programs—is having a number of disturbing knock‐on effects within my area. Crime and juvenile delinquency, family breakdown and domestic violence and the most serious heroin problem in Australia are all taking a devastating toll on my community, and lying at its heart is the region's endemic and deep unemployment. The Prime Minister offers reactionary, bandaid solutions to these problems. He announces $84 million over three years to combat drugs and $25 million over 3½ years for domestic violence, yet he fails to appreci ate that to really make an impression on these social problems he needs to attack their root causes, including unemployment. Axing $2 billion from labour market programs is quite plainly not the way to go about solving unemployment; neither will fringe feelgood programs like work for the dole have much of an impact on reducing the numbers in the jobless queues. Only good public policy is going to do that and good public policy includes a thorough and encompassing program of labour market reforms.

The people of Prospect—not only those who are unemployed but also their families and their dependents—say, `We feel like we have been left in the lurch by this government.' My people take no joy in discovering that our Prime Minister, from his fireside armchair at Kirribilli House, feels it unnecessary to lead his government in fighting an all‐out war to reduce unemployment in this country. If anything, it leaves my constituents feeling abandoned and left behind.

Over the last 20 months the Howard government has also left behind a number of the promises it made while in opposition. The Howard government came to power promising the people of my electorate adequate, affordable and available community based child care. In relation to child care, the Prime Minister said:
It's the role of the government to facilitate choice. Now, that's the policy, that's the philosophy, the attitude, the approach.

After cutting $820 million from the community based child‐care sector around Australia, the only choices this government has left thousands of families is whether they leave their jobs to stay home and look after the kids, whether they call on relatives or friends to mind their children or whether they place their kids in unregulated and unaccredited backyard childminding operations. My electorate has been devastated by the Howard government's cuts to child care. Where two years ago some community based centres in my electorate would have seen around 300 children coming through their doors each week, some of them now find it difficult even to maintain 100 regular attendees. There are, indeed, enough vacancies in the community based centres in my electorate for at least two centres to be closed down. Fees have skyrocketed by up to $40 per child per week at some centres, services have been dropped and expert staff have been sacked.

There is also anecdotal evidence to suggest that many parents in my community are leaving their children with out-of-work young people—many of whom are not much more than kids themselves—and who have no childminding expertise or knowledge. They are paying these young people a nominal fee in order to keep their kids under supervision, but who knows what really happens to them in these places while their parents are at work?

Child‐care funding, however, is not the only thing we have lost in my electorate. We have seen the demise of the highly successful family resource centre, Ettinger House. Ettinger House played an extremely valuable role in coordinating and informing local community groups and individuals to help them find the support services they needed. Now that Ettinger House has been closed down, we have lost a valuable link out of our community's welfare safety net.

We have lost a considerable amount of funding from the Fairfield Legal Aid service as well. Fairfield Local Court, not five minutes walk from my electorate office, is one of the busiest courts in New South Wales. As a result, Fairfield Legal Aid is also one of the busiest offices of its kind.

I can assure the government that its cuts to legal aid have not lessened the work burden on the people in this office. There is no doubt that, because of these cuts, the underprivileged people in my community are not receiving the legal representation that is due to them. If people are going unrepresented, that means people are not getting the justice they deserve. That people in modern day Australia are being deprived of their natural rights—their natural recourse to justice—because of cuts by the Howard government is deplorable in the extreme.

The people of Prospect have also lost Commonwealth funding for public dental health care at the local Fairfield Hospital. When Commonwealth funding cut out on 1 January this year, Fairfield Hospital's public dental health clinic endeavoured to keep business going as usual. Seven months later, it realised that business as usual without Commonwealth support was simply impossible. The General Manager of the Fairfield Health Service, Mr Andrew Bernard, was forced, on 1 July this year, to suspend the hospital's dental care waiting list, a list which had ballooned considerably since Commonwealth funding was axed, in order to clear the backlog of names that were already there. By 1 July, there were 3,000 patients waiting on the general dental care waiting list and approximately 1,800 patients waiting on the denture waiting list. In the 5½ months since the lists have been suspended, hospital management has had turn away anybody wishing to receive any kind of dental treatment.

So where have the hundreds of people—most of them elderly pensioners—who looked to Fairfield Hospital for help with their dental problems gone over the last 5½ months? Their teeth certainly have not been fixed. They have not been able to do it themselves. These people still need either new dentures or teeth care. They still need fillings or caps; they still need to have their teeth removed. What is happening to them? The answer is very plain. They have not disappeared; they are suffering in silence. The Howard government took $100 million out of this program and has, instead, wasted it on an ineffective private health insurance incentive scheme. Elderly people with rotten teeth in my electorate are eating their meals through straws and will continue to do so for months to come—and possibly even years into the future—until those funds taken out by the Howard government are returned.

If people require emergency treatment because of their teeth, there is still no guarantee they will receive a prompt consultation. Fairfield Hospital's 24‐hour emergency dental service is most days anything but. People have to call the clinic in the morning to make an appointment. If they do not get through—and, believe me, I have been told it is not uncommon for the phones to be engaged for hours at a time; I have also tried myself to get through to test it—then they must try again the next day or the day after that, and if they are again unsuccessful then the day after that or, indeed, the day after that. You try putting up with an abscess for as long as that!

All the while these people are in excruciating pain, but the hospital does not have the resources to help them because, again, the Howard government has withdrawn them. This government has introduced Third World health values into what should be a First World facility at Fairfield Hospital, leaving both the staff and patients to pick up the pieces. They have just been left with it. I think that is an absolutely woeful state of affairs to have arrived at.

When one talks about the past 20 months under the Howard government, one could not possibly go past without commenting on its complete incapacity to come up with a fair and comprehensible nursing home policy. As the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Beazley) said in the House yesterday, we have seen 12 backflips on this policy in the last eight months. You would think that this government—after 12 backflips, after the fear and anxiety they had whipped up among the elderly and their families in the community, after the bad poll results had started pouring in—would finally have realised the error of its ways and made a full and unqualified retreat. It has tried to portray itself as having done just that, but the fine print says something different.

The elderly of Australia need to be made aware of this fact. Their home is still not safe under this government. The government's nursing home policy remains unconscionable and unfair.

When we look back at the issues which I have just raised, it is really no wonder that we did not receive a progress report from the Prime Minister this year. There is simply no progress to report. The Australian people deserve to face the new millennium united, a people with a common voice and a common spirit. We do not deserve to live in a country divided by mean-spiritedness, by jealousy and by despair. Unfortunately, that is the course that this Howard government has set us upon. It is a course which has the Prime Minister's fingerprints all over it. It is a course, I believe, from which any fair-minded Australian should recoil in horror.

In the few minutes still left to me, I would like to put on record also my appreciation to the Speaker, to you, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, to the clerks and to all staff who have managed this parliament other the last 12 months. I would like to thank all of the attendants and all those involved in providing the services that we need so desperately to be able to represent our electorates in this place. I would like to wish them all a very merry Christmas and may we have a very happy and prosperous 1998.

I would also like to put on record my appreciation to my personal staff—to Julie Starr, to Brian Thompson and to Paul Andrews. They are three people who work very well within my office. None of us are an island. We cannot do what we do in representing our people and think we can do it by ourselves. All of us depend on our staff. I have always been very dependent on mine. I have a very loyal staff. I would like to have their names placed on the record of this parliament and to express to them through the Hansard how much I sincerely appreciate them as well.

I thank my electorate for the opportunity they have given to me to continue to represent them in this place. I deem it an honour and a privilege, and I will continue to do my best to represent them in a fair way and in the only way in which I can—and that is to give of myself over 100 per cent. I wish everyone concerned all the very best. Let us see that in 1998 we go forward with the calmness and even‐handedness of which I spoke in this speech. We do not need to divide this nation; we do not need to divide this country. What we need is leadership that will unite us and keep this country going in the right direction. Let us be proud to be Australians. But, more importantly, let us be proud to have Australia as a part of the world in which we live.

The expectation comment that the ABS put for the September quarter is `expectations for the mining industry are indicating particularly strong growth'. The current estimate for mining investment expectations is 18.7 per cent higher than for the same estimate last year. The investment is there in the minerals and resources industry. It is important to appreciate the link between the state of investment in the industry with the state of exploration activity. We are expecting the next lot of exploration figures to be out before the end of the year. The most recent actual and expected private mineral exploration figures released by the ABS are for the June quarter, which were released at the end of September. It is interesting to try to make some assessment of these figures. The ABS survey for the June quarter says:
The upward trend in exploration expenditure since the June quarter 1993 continued in the June quarter 1997.

As the honourable member for Corio (Mr O'Connor), our spokesperson for Northern Australia, who has an interest in these matters, will appreciate, we have seen an upward trend in exploration expenditure since the June quarter of 1993. The report continues:

Between the March and the June quarters 1997, the trend estimate increased by 7.0% . . . With growth continuing in each quarter during 1996‐97, the trend estimate for the June quarter 1997 was 20.7% higher than for the June quarter 1996.
The substantive point I want to make will be of interest to the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) because it relates to gold. The ABS report goes on to say:
The total mineral exploration expenditure for 1996‐97 financial year was $1,157.0m, an increase of $196.8m (20.5%) from 1995‐96. Exploration for gold accounted for 62.8% of total expenditure.

The report refers to gold expenditure being in the range of 62 to 63 per cent. This point is relevant because this is for the June quarter. In the few days after the end of the June quarter, 3 and 4 July, we saw the RBA decision on the gold sell‐off and the Treasurer's lamentable comments on that announcement, which effectively destroyed the sentiment for gold in the marketplace. The next set of exploration figures that we will get to look at are potentially very worrying. We have seen an increase in the trend in exploration since the June quarter 1993, but 62 per cent to 63 per cent of that is made up of gold. There is absolutely no doubt now, and I am sure the honourable member for Kalgoorlie will agree, that we are now facing effectively a crisis in Australia's gold industry.

The gold price as I walked to the chamber was $US285. We have seen in recent days one symbolic US dollar amount for the spot price of gold—$US300—breached. Today as I walked into the chamber another symbolic level—$US285—was breached. We are seeing enormous difficulties for the gold industry and that will run through into exploration. Despite those strong investment figures we saw released last week for new private capital expenditure, despite that strength in exploration since the June quarter 1993, there is a very serious and grave risk that, as a result of the damage that the Treasurer did to the sentiment for gold, we will see a significant buffeting of those exploration figures.

I have previously drawn to the attention of the House, so far as gold is concerned, some specific projects that have either chosen not to expand or have effectively closed. Perhaps the two most noteworthy of those are Western Mining's decision not to proceed with its $157 million St Ives project expansion as a direct consequence of gold price difficulties. Most recently we have seen the closure of the Mount Todd goldmine in the Northern Territory. I was both interested and concerned earlier this week to see a report in the Melbourne Age of an analysis which suggests that, as a consequence of the slump in the gold price, there is now a forecast that the production of gold in Australia will contract from approximately 300 tonnes a year to 200 tonnes—a 30 per cent drop in gold output. On Monday's or Tuesday's prices, which were closer to $US300 than $US285, that would come in at a loss of income to the industry in the order of $1.3 to $1.4 billion.

With gold making up 62 to 63 per cent of our exploration we now run the risk of seeing, because of the circumstances relating to gold, up to a 30 per cent drop in production. The consequences which flow will not be adverse for just exploration, they will be adverse for very many regional centres in Western Australia and elsewhere. One thing is not generally understood about the gold industry. Most members have an understanding of the bigger projects and the bigger companies, but this is a very diverse industry. It is situated in towns such as Meekatharra, Cue, Leonora, Laverton and Southern Cross. It is not just the super pits in Kalgoorlie or the large mines like Mount Todd or Telfer.

What are some of the other difficulties facing the minerals and resources industry at present? One is the commodity price cycle, which in very many respects is running against us on just about every front. I have mentioned gold; I will not lay that on with a trowel. I will move to nickel. One of the things which buttressed the north‐eastern goldfields of Western Australia generally when the RBA made its decision and the Treasurer made his lamentable comments about gold was that things were looking very prospective for nickel in July. There are a number of nickel projects on the books or prospective in Western Australia. Unfortunately, since that time we have seen dramatically adverse consequences for the world nickel price. This has largely come about as a consequence of the former Soviet Union effectively flooding the world market with recyclable nickel in the guise of stainless steel. Now nickel is under severe pressure so far as the nickel price is concerned.

That lay at the heart of the decision by Dominion Mining recently to announce that the Yakabindie project would effectively be put on hold for a couple of years. I know that the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr Tim Fischer), the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) and the honourable member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) sought to link that directly to native title. I well know that Dominion have had their native title difficulties, but the reasons articulated by the chairman and managing director of Dominion at the time of that announcement in Perth last week were directly related to the world nickel price and the slump in that market. So the commodity price cycle is running against us, and what is true of nickel is true of coal and a range of other commodities.

The second general difficulty that minerals and resources face is what we now describe as the `Asian crisis'. I noticed a report in the Australian Financial Review by Bruce Hextall, the Australian Financial Review's resources writer, which was headed `Fight for life as Asian crisis hits resources'. In his article, Mr Hextall made a series of points which I thought were quite relevant, quite prescient and also, from the industry's point of view, very serious factors which need to be considered. Mr Hextall made the point that the commodity price cycle is running against us, and the Asian difficulties will not help that. Secondly, he made the point that much of our export in minerals and resources goes to the Asian area and that the downturn in the Asian economies will not help that. He also made the point that the institutional investors, whilst there has been some rebound in the course of this week, are now effectively walking away from investing in minerals and resources stock. Just as the gold producers and gold miners have found in the last four or five months, there is now a general difficulty in raising capital so far as minerals and resources projects are concerned. The sorts of comments that Mr Hextall made in the course of his article draw some of those strands together and put some of the industry's current difficulties into some context.

Underlying all of this is the general philosophical approach which now needs to underline our public policy approach to minerals and resources. This goes not just to exploration and investment but to production generally. If I can use the quaint phrase `in the old days', the competition for capital for investment in Australia's minerals and resources industries used to be effectively the choice which was made in boardrooms in Melbourne, Sydney or, to a lesser extent, Perth as to whether you would invest your money into a gold‐copper mine in New South Wales, a base metals mine in Queensland or gold or, more recently, iron ore in Western Australia. The various state governments would put forward their various incentive packages to try to attract capital to their state for that investment.

The difficulty for Australia now as a nation state is that that is no longer the competition. The competition for investment capital for minerals and resources is now a global competition. So when the map is unfurled it is not a map of Australia, it is a map of the world, and the decisions which are made in boardrooms in Melbourne, Perth, Sydney, London and the United States are decisions which determine whether investment capital is made in Australia, Canada, the United States, Argentina, Indonesia, India or Brazil.

The great competition for us now is competition for international capital for investment purposes in the minerals and resources area. I frankly think that one thing we have not done at all at the national level is to put the public policy ruler under our attractiveness or international competitiveness for investment in minerals and resources industries. We have to a very large extent, if not to a complete extent, taken for granted the great attractiveness of the industries we have: the world‐class ore bodies, the great prospecting skills, the great exploration skills, the great engineering ingenuity and the capacity to run the best and most efficient mines in the world.

TALK.START.PARA: —Workers' skills.

—The member for Kalgoorlie is quite right. We are effectively taking those for granted, resting on our laurels and not putting our minds to or the public policy ruler under the question: what are we doing to make sure we attract international capital for minerals and resources? I will give a couple of examples. If you, like MIM or Norths, want to get the Alumbrera project going in Argentina, you turn up in Argentina and you have a meeting with the President. The President hands over a personally signed copy of the tax regime which says that there is a stable tax regime in place for 30 years, and you make your judgments accordingly. That is one thing which Argentina is doing in seeking to attract capital.

BREAK.PARA: I noticed the other day that Comalco, who are contemplating an expansion of their activities so far as alumina is concerned in Gladstone, were referring to the choice between Gladstone or Malaysia—which are the two options they have on the books. The point that was made by a representative of Comalco at a conference earlier this week was that they were not so much worrying about the sovereign risk which might come from the PNG Chevron pipeline possibility but the fact that the Malaysians were prepared to ascribe to Comalco's alumina refinery the denomination of `project of national significance', which brings with it, effectively, a 100 per cent development allowance incentive.

They are the sorts of things that other countries are doing. What are we doing? I think, frankly, that we are resting on our laurels. I make the point about the Alumbrera mine, which is a very good project that displays the world-class skills that our Australian minerals and resources industry has. Whilst the Argentinian regime is a 30‐year tax freeze, that project only went ahead so far as the Australian consortium was concerned because EFIC, our own export finance institution, put together an international consortium to effect sovereign risk insurance. This is a point I have made previously to the representatives of the minerals and resources and industries: we may well be going through our access to title difficulties, which on this side we are doing our best to seek to resolve, but there is a qualitative difference between having an access to land difficulty and having your assets compulsorily acquired without compensation.

The Deputy Prime Minister stands up in this place and talks about sovereign risk. Sovereign risk is a very important factor, and access is one of the things which goes to the notion of sovereign risk, but one of the great strengths we have—which is a strength that Argentina and Papua New Guinea do not currently have—is the notion that there is no risk under our regime of one's assets being acquired without compensation. So when investment is made in Australia one thing you do not need to worry about is sovereign risk insurance.

On those investment and exploration figures, whilst some of the cyclical things are causing difficulty and while there are currently difficulties so far as access to title is concerned, there are great prospects and potential. I think that one of our greatest prospects for Australia is that we now have a much greater capacity than in the past to start to engage much more assiduously in downstream processing. One of the driving factors behind this is the reality and the prospect throughout Australia of much more internationally cost competitive energy with the development of a whole range of new gas production and pipeline projects.

In Queensland, for example, it is the pipeline from Ballera to Mount Isa and, once you get to Mount Isa, you might just as well go to Gunpowder and, once you get to Gunpowder, you might just as well go to Century Zinc. There is the prospect of the Chevron PNG pipeline. My own view is that that has every likelihood of success. We have seen the heads of agreement between Comalco and Chevron for the joint development of the pipeline and the Comalco refinery in Gladstone and recently we saw the native title access agreement from Gladstone to the end of Cape York. I have no especial knowledge, but I would not be surprised if Chevron representatives were currently floating around the back blocks, making inquiries about sovereign risk insurance so far as PNG is concerned.

I have always been cautiously optimistic that that project might go ahead simply on the basis that the oil pays for the gas. The gas comes from the Kutubu oil‐gas field. There is too much gas there to reinject, there is too much gas there to flare and there is no domestic market in PNG, so the most sensible thing to do economically and environmentally is to put a pipe over the top of the hill and bring it down to a market. If that goes ahead, you will see that adding to the competitive nature of the cost of energy in Queensland. We are a bit slower off the mark in Western Australia, but we will get there. Bringing down the cost of energy to internationally competitive rates will be that which will drive downstream processing in Australia in future years. So, while there are difficulties currently associated with our great minerals and resources industries, there are great prospects for investment, great prospects for exploration and great prospects for downstream processing. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with great pleasure that I rise to give my wholehearted support to this series of appropriation bills. That pleasure is contained in the appropriation of $10 million for the Commonwealth's Hunter assistance package and a further $1 million for the Hunter Regional Tourism Organisation to assist in the development of tourism in the Hunter region. It is part of a joint cooperative effort by the Howard government, the New South Wales government and BHP to finance projects that will generate longer term economic and employment opportunities in the Hunter. It is a commitment of substantive public funds to bolster the people of the Hunter's confidence, help generate new, exciting business proposals and foster growth and development in related sectors that will, in part, secure employment for existing steelworkers across the Hunter, as well as expand the region's manufacturing mix.

SPEECH.PARA: The hard and fast reason for the Commonwealth's $10 million contribution emanates, of course, from the announced closure by BHP of its integrated steel making facility in Newcastle at the end of 1999, resulting in 2,500 direct job losses at the historic steelworks. The collective funding package includes $10 million from the federal government, $10 million from the New South Wales government and an estimated figure of at least $5 million committed in kind by BHP. To say that the Hunter assistance package has been well received would be an understatement. Upon its announcement in May, over 50 legitimate applications for financial assistance alone were forwarded collectively to my office and also via Senator John Tierney's to the most competent hands of the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Michael Ronaldson.

The statement of principle by which the Commonwealth wishes to provide support to the Hunter, in the context of BHP's decision to wind back its steel operations, has five criteria. The first is to facilitate access to existing adjustment assistance, particularly labour market measures. This point has been met in part by separate funding assistance on 21 May by former Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Amanda Vanstone, in excess of $2 million, which included extra funding of NEIS places, a skills audit and direct manufacturer‐worker assistance in retraining and reskilling.

The second point is to provide coordination between existing Commonwealth services and programs having a substantial impact on the Hunter's economy. This coordinated approach includes a review of transport links, investment facilitation and, in particular, a focus on our defence industry, which alone has got to be one of the most exciting things to be happening to the local Hunter economy.

The defence industry, unbeknown to many, is the biggest employing sector collectively in the Hunter. More to the point, it is an exciting, new age, high‐tech industry which has the 21st century written all over it. Whether it be for the $850 million lead‐in fighter project—in which British Aerospace Australia, in unison with local firm Hunter Aerospace, has made Williamtown the major support facility for this venture—or naval shipping refits and construction undertaken by the likes of FORGACS and ADI, including the minehunter and frigate modules, or perhaps one day scoring the lion's share of the airborne early warning and control aircraft, the AEWACs, I have issued a call to arms to the Hunter's business, civic and political leaders not to drop the ball on the exciting future prospects that the defence industry has for our region.

Thirdly, the Hunter assistance package would ensure the support of agreed economic development priorities and have the support of all key players. That in itself was played out just yesterday with the announcement of the first round of agreed federal funding totalling $3 million towards the cost of electricity infrastructure on Kooragang Island, provided a feasibility study announced by ANI produces a satisfactory outcome for the construction of a new steel making plant in the Hunter. That figure is being complemented by the state government's commitment of $2 million towards the electricity infrastructure and a grant of $4 million worth of public Crown land to ANI. I will come back to that point in a moment.

Fourthly, the funding is to be provided for key initiatives leading to sustainable employment generation, be it in the private or public sector. That clearly will be the case if ANI proceeds with the proposed 75‐tonne electric arc furnace, vertical caster and associated equipment to manufacture billets and ingots, at a cost of approximately $125 million. That clearly will be the case as the Commonwealth in due course reveals the rest of its hand in the weeks and months ahead on the rest of its proposed spending commitments allocated within this appropriation bill.

Finally, the crux of this package includes the monitoring of all other Commonwealth programs that may have an impact on the Hunter. One such initiative is the $1 million allocated to Hunter Tourism for the continuation of their highly successful tourism development strategy. Tourism is an industry that some in the Hunter get a little dismissive of. Tourism is seen by many to be our region's economic panacea, and I have got to say I concur with that sentiment. However, in the same breath many simply do not do recognise the fantastic future that tourism has in the Hunter in terms of the opportunities it provides in future jobs and investment. Tourism in the Hunter is big business, and it delivers significant outcomes for a region which is attempting to re‐establish itself and to cut out a new image, a new direction, in the brave new world of globalised economics for the next century. It delivers substantial numbers of jobs—the perennial economic question which faces the Hunter's decision makers.

Tourism in the Hunter now generates one in nine of all new jobs created locally. Recently the Minister for the Environment (Senator Hill) jointly opened with me the new $2.5 million ecotourism lodge development at the pristine and world renowned Barrington Guest House at the foothills of the Barrington Tops National Park, some of the most intense and exquisite rainforest in Australia. Minister Hill's comments after an overnight stay in one of the new ecotourism cabins was that this was the type of attraction that tourists from all over the world would want to come to in the years ahead. Barrington Guest House, which got into ecotourism decades before it became a buzz word, is very much the way of the future for the tourism industry in the Hunter to exploit sensibly and rationally to create great local economic and employment advantage. Last year $756 million was spent by tourists and visitors coming to the Hunter. That is $756 million that goes through hundreds of small business cash registers: hotels, restaurants and cafes, retail outlets, caravan parks and amusement centres, to name but a few.

Hunter Tourism, who have successfully assisted tourism via their slick, chic advertising and marketing campaign both at home and abroad, have been able to help lure a growth of 35 per cent in the number of foreign tourists to the Hunter in the past four years. They were doing a great job back then, and into the future they will continue to do a great job in being one of the key promoters of the Hunter to the rest of Australia and the world. To put that factor into perspective, for every 18 foreign tourists that come and stay in the Hunter, one new real job in the region is created and, importantly, sustained. The $1 million will have $500,000 allocated for a key infrastructure initiative to foster further growth in tourism, $300,000 for Hunter Tourism marketing and $200,000 for training initiatives. Expressions of interest have now closed and, with the Office of National Tourism, those allocated moneys will be reviewed before their future announcement.

Of recent times, the Labor Party has made much ado, so to speak, about the fact that the Hunter region has an unemployment rate some four to 4½ per cent higher than the state or national average. There is no denying that fact. The Hunter needs to do much better on the employment front. It is a problem that grew bigger and bigger in the 1980s. When it was not effectively addressed back then, it bolted out to an incredible 17 per cent plus in official terms during Labor's self‐induced recession of the early 1990s, and now hovers between 11.5 and 12.5 per cent. There are many reasons for this in the last decade and a half, as there were missed opportunities, including the wind‐backs and shutdowns of BHP, the old State Dockyards and Carrington Slipways, to name a few.

Yes, our regional economy has restructured—or, more to the point, it was forced to restructure—and on many fronts business, government and the community are taking up the challenge. But we must be prepared to continue to think outside the square. In recent months I suggested, for instance, that as a region we needed to collectively examine the future operations of our domestic airports, of the reality that the ever continuing expansion of Williamtown Airport had to be put in perspective with the now much smaller air operations at Belmont Aeropelican. In the medium term, I said, the future of Belmont Airport should be put under the microscope and perhaps, in the interest of the Greater Hunter, have its services consolidated at Williamtown. That caused a few rumblings and has caused a fair bit of heated debate, but there are plenty of people, including, for instance, David Simmons from the Newcastle Chamber of Commerce, a respected former Labor member and tourism minister in this parliament, who think it is a damn good idea, with immense downstream benefits for a variety of industries and with the ability to bolster freight movements out of the Hunter.

The point I was trying to make with all that is that we must be prepared to be a little bit different; to be a little, should I say, like Jeffrey Kennett and have the intestinal fortitude to say that we want the Hunter to go forward. That is the symbolism behind this Commonwealth assistance package to the Hunter. Just as BHP says goodbye to steel making in Newcastle at the turn of the century, I very much predict that new industries, new exciting businesses, will rise like a phoenix from these ashes. Put simply, the sky is not going to fall in on the Hunter—indeed, I am so bold as to predict that it could even be a new dawn. Of course the future closure of BHP's steel making facility will, in raw numbers, further increase the percentage unemployment rate, but the Howard-Fischer government is not about to let that happen. It would have been easy for the Howard government to abandon me as the occupant of the Liberal Party's most marginal seat in this House and just say, `Well, for the cost for one seat, it is not worth the investment.'

However, this government is not like that. And this has nothing to do with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) particularly wanting to keep Bob Baldwin in parliament. This is about a belief in the people of the Hunter. This is about caring for people as individuals and not treating them as disposal statistics, as Labor has historically tended to do in the Hunter. This debate today is about an investment in the people of the Hunter. It is about developing a plan that can and will work, despite the protestations of others from across the political divide.

The substantial upgrading of electricity infrastructure on Kooragang Island as part of the first round of the Commonwealth's promised assistance package to the Hunter paints a very real picture that job creation and fostering new industry development in our region remain a clear focus. Both I and Senator John Tierney, the Howard government's other representative in the Hunter, have played active behind the scenes roles to promote jobs and investment friendly projects that economically reposition the Hunter for the 21st century. Together we applauded yesterday's funding assistance for upgraded electricity infrastructure on Kooragang Island, seen as the precursor to ANI constructing its new steel operations.

BREAK.PARA: To attract further industry to the Hunter and to best utilise the untapped resource that Kooragang Island is for the local economy, we need to ensure that adequate infrastructure is in place. Being fair dinkum about ensuring that steel making is not lost to the Hunter and about expanding the region's tentacles to attract new industry means that simple things like getting the infrastructure nuts and bolts in place have to be a priority. Opening the door for new industry development, expanded investment and job creation on Kooragang Island will mean that what many have seen as an industrial lemon will become very sweet tasting in terms of the economic benefits it will deliver.

Overall, Kooragang Island, with its direct access to the port of Newcastle, to the adjacent rail services and to the nearby air services at Williamtown, makes plenty of economic sense if the Hunter's industry base is to continue to expand and reinvent itself. For the Commonwealth to ensure long‐term job sustainability and new employment opportunities for our youth and for displaced BHP employees, we have to show Australia and the world that on every level the Hunter is an attractive place for industry to cost effectively set up shop. Yesterday's announcement shows that. And it is a case of `watch this space' for what is in store to round out the rest of the Commonwealth's $10 million plus investment. After all, this is about repositioning the Hunter and about government planting the seed for private industry to overcome BHP's cessation of steel making in the region.

Finally, I wish to address what, after intensive lobbying by me, Senator Tierney and other interested parties keen to see the Hunter hurtling forward economically, is the issue of the government's long awaited industry statement. The Labor Party have, as I have picked up from time to time, tried to draw a line in the sand. They try to say that industry policy is off the rails and that this government is visionless when it comes to industry policy. I will take that a step further. The member for Hotham (Mr Crean) is trying to downplay manufacturing in bond. In today's Newcastle Herald, he says that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has:

. . . got to do it. He's got to announce MIB, but I fear that it will be the only announcement of benefit to Newcastle. What they'll try and do is say they've sorted Newcastle out by giving them Manufacturing in Bond.
Bless my cotton socks, Simon: if we deliver manufacturing in bond, we may just do that.

For the people of the Hunter, I have been taking up a last‐ditch fight to see that this region is a direct beneficiary of a new approach to industry and a fresh approach to manufacturing. Pressing all the buttons means trying to ensure that the Commonwealth government approves foreign trade zones or, in just as practical terms, a manufacturing in bond arrangement for the Hunter.

Such a policy announcement will back to the hilt revelations by firms such as DHL Worldwide, planet earth's largest air freight distributor, that a change in the federal tax and duty structure by this government could bring a windfall of investment at Williamtown airport by way of an Asian warehouse headquarters for the corporate giant. When I recently launched Elite Distribution Services' new $1.2 million headquarters in October, which is now the Hunter's largest transport distributor, its heightened support for any such change in the reapplication of taxes and duties on exported goods as a way to value add and boost local manufacturing could have it playing a greatly expanded role, as could BHP with its Steel River project.

An endorsement of manufacturing in bond was recommended by the Steel Industry Inquiry Committee, of which I was a member, and featured as part of the government's response to the Mortimer report. To endorse manufacturing in bond will very much assist the exciting developments at Williamtown airport, consolidating it as an avionics and aeronautical hub.

That is one of the key visions I have had for the Hunter since my election to this House. A simple nip and tuck to change the federal tax policy and reinstate a policy which the Hawke government dropped like a hot potato in 1987 could bring DHL and its massive resource base to the Hunter. All that is needed is a simple nip and tuck to remove restrictions on the use of section 79(3) of the Customs Act to allow a warehouse licence to authorise blending, packaging, processing, trading or other specified activities. That might not be exciting but it would mean federal tax policy could deliver real job and investment outcomes almost in an instant in the Hunter.

That measure would not just be for DHL to exploit. The success and growth of Elite Express as regional agents for Australia's major distribution firms, including Ansett Air Freight, AUSDOC and Australian Pharmaceutical Industries proves the Hunter has an exciting future that expands far beyond being a steel region in the eyes of Australia.

In conclusion, when I speak of vision, you will not find more bucket loads of it than in a speech by Chris Huggins, group general manager of A Goninan and Co. during a speech to an industrial relations seminar at Salamander Bay on 31 October. He reflected on industry policy, and I do not think anyone could put it much more eloquently than he did:

How can it be that a nation so young, focussing itself towards international competitiveness and approaching the inevitability of becoming a republic, has no clear notion of what our national interest really is, for example, in manufacturing and employment generation?

Would any management team steer their company into a new market without a clear understanding of the factors affecting that market and how the company's strategy would impact on its workforce and shareholders?
The fact is that industry must invest to survive and government must provide leadership to facilitate and support this.

The Hunter's regional economy is increasingly integrated with global markets for its resources, manufactures and services, and I invite you to contemplate the potential of a "new platform" for export‐orientated activities that could be triggered, such as the Made in Bond zone.
Chris Huggins is spot on the mark.

I think Chris Huggins will be impressed with next Monday's long awaited industry statement. Hunter industry has a great spokesman and a great lateral thinker in Chris Huggins. Let me tell you, this government has done some thinking on this subject, and the thinking it has done is pretty lateral.
