SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Graeme, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to these appropriation bills, I think I ought to make it quite clear that the problems facing Australia are not guns, drugs, sex—or rock and roll, for that matter. The abiding cancer eating at this nation is the high level of unemployment and the fact that governments no longer take the people of Australia into their confidence. Because the policies of Liberal and Labor are so similar, the people of Australia are disenfranchised and are no longer party to the government. The problem of unemployment is recognised by the many previous members who have spoken, but they do not seem to understand that their own policies, the policies of their respective parties, have contributed to this problem.

SPEECH.PARA: In his very worthwhile contribution, the member for Hunter (Mr Fitzgibbon) talked about the problems he has experienced with industrial relations. There is absolutely no doubt about that, if we go down the road the government is proposing, we advantage multinational companies to the disadvantage of workers in Australia. Frankly, I do not think the multinational companies need this sort of advantage, for one thing is sure: these large companies never, ever operate with Australia's national interest as a priority. It may be a by‐product of their actions, but their actions are always in their own perceived interests. If we benefit, we are simply fortunate in that regard. The enormous advantage which the banning of secondary boycotts bestows on multinational companies has to be considered.

The member for Prospect (Mrs Crosio) spoke very forcefully in this debate lamenting unemployment, particularly in the western suburbs. A job created anywhere in Australia has the impact of stopping people from one place moving to another. I am very keen to see jobs created in the western suburbs of Sydney or Melbourne—or anywhere else in Australia, for that matter—because it simply stops those people coming to my electorate and looking for work. It was under the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating, that this nation was effectively deskilled. Paul Keating told caucus that the future lay in the service sector. The service sector is political code for tourism. As you would know yourself, Mr Deputy Speaker, when jobs were destroyed in the Tasmanian timber industry those people did not find jobs in the tourist industry. When the tourist industry got off the ground, that in turn was attacked by the Greens. Across Australia we have a situation where workers are being made unemployed, their wives now work part time and no‐one factors in the cost to society of the kids who are out of control.

This is the real issue for Australia, but it is not being addressed by the government. We have to reskill this country. This country, which arguably used to make the best metal trades workers in world, now produces drink waiters. They may be very good drink waiters. The member for Prospect indicated in her speech that she thinks the future lies in tourism. I can tell the comrade from Prospect that it is not so. Tourism is a very good ancillary industry, it is one we want, but it has to be an ancillary industry because expenditure on tourism is highly discretionary.

The member for Perth (Mr Stephen Smith) talked about mineral development. Yes, there was an upturn in mineral development last year. What he failed to mention was that it was very largely brownfields development—development around existing mines. Drilling and exploration outside that type of development is, in fact, tapering off quite considerably. The member for Perth is absolutely right when he points to the downturn in gold. Gold is a very substantial part of that exploration program. Goldmining has taken a terrible knock because of the stupidity of the Reserve Bank in selling our reserves. The justification was that it was being done by banks in Europe. Not one bank in Europe is involved in a goldmining industry. Their parameters are much different from ours. Gold is Australia's second largest industry, but the Reserve Bank effectively acted to damage that industry. The asinine comments of the Treasurer (Mr Costello), which now are a matter of record, simply made it worse. The truth is that gold is going through a very bad price downturn, but the companies are pretty well hedged. The companies can probably weather that downturn in price for two years, particularly if it is matched by a declining Australian dollar. The industry did not need the additional burden placed on it by the stupidity of the Reserve Bank and the Treasurer.

However, the member for Perth made too light of the impact of native title on exploration. Native title quite clearly is a real risk to sovereign rights. There is absolutely no doubt that native title is playing its part in stopping mining exploration in Australia. It is very easy for people from Sydney or Melbourne to take the high moral ground. But destroying rural Australia will eventually impact on those cities. That impact is likely to take effect very quickly. For instance, the goldmining industry probably generates more jobs in the cities than any other sector of the mining industry. These are manufacturing jobs, basically in Melbourne and Sydney. Those members from Melbourne and Sydney who come into this House should reflect on that.

I want to read an article which I think is germane. It deals with the myth of an American free press. There is no doubt that what is true in America is absolutely true in Australia. This was said by John Swinton, Chief of Staff of the New York Times, considered by his peers to be the dean of his profession, when asked to give a toast at the New York Press Club in 1953:
There is no such thing, at this date of the world's history, in America, as an independent press. You know it and I know it.

There is not one of you who dares to write your honest opinions, and if you did you know beforehand that it would never appear in print. I am paid weekly for keeping my honest opinion out of the paper I am connected with. Others of you are paid similar salaries for similar things, and any of you who would be so foolish as to write honest opinion would be out on the streets looking for another job. If I allowed my honest opinions to appear in one issue of my paper, before twenty‐four hours my occupation would be gone.

The business of the journalists is to destroy the truth, to lie outright, to pervert, to vilify, to fawn at the feet of mammon, and to sell his country and his race for his daily bread. You know it and I know it, and what folly is this toasting an independent press?

We are the tools and vassals of rich men behind the scenes. We are the jumping jacks, they pull the strings and we dance. Our talents, our possibilities and our lives are all the property of other men. We are intellectual prostitutes.

That very honest summation of the American press is absolutely true of Australia. There is no doubt that with its greater variety of ownership, the American press is much freer than the press in Australia.

This brings me to what I consider to be the absolutely irresponsible behaviour of the press with respect to the reporting of the Wik debate. There is absolutely no doubt that this weak and wishy-washy legislation of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) does not go anywhere near as far as Keating thought his legislation went. Keating was adamant that pastoral leases extinguished native title. Indeed, in the act of 1993 they went to the trouble of making valid those leases which would otherwise have been invalid, thus extinguishing native title on them. Keating also thought there was a prima facie requirement in his act for them to show a real, long-term association with the land.

In the early days, a tribunal was enforcing that. In my own area—an area of Australia where there are more native title claims than anywhere else in Australia, where miners have to put up with up to a dozen overlapping claims—the tribunal was actually rejecting claims because they were without merit or had insufficient evidence. Then we had the Federal Court intervening and saying that, because it was in the preamble of the act—a very badly written act—or not in the act itself, it was not part of the act and the court was free to accept claims but not reject them. It was because of that decision, from that point onwards, that the right to negotiate became the right to extortion. Yet, you find the Labor Party here will not maintain that situation and will talk about the value of association with the land, which is basically impossible to prove or to disprove. It clearly means there will be ongoing confusion—confusion for ever and ever. It is so obvious what it means to oppose a sunset clause—as they do. It means that future native title claims will be contingent upon the findings of ore bodies, as though there is some mechanism there that triggers it. Of course, there is a mechanism that does trigger it, and that mechanism is unabashed greed.

The people of Australia ought to know this; they ought to have an understanding of it. But they do not because the media of this country has been so intent on railroading the government, condemning the government. The one‐sided reporting and the lack of understanding we have had from the journalists of this country are an indictment of the level of journalism in Australia. They should bear in mind the words of that great journalist who said `the bubble is blown and the bubble is pricked by you and such as you'. They have an enormous responsibility. To date, they have not accepted that responsibility. I see very little evidence in the press gallery in this place of any sign or sense of integrity.

I now want to talk about trade opportunities. We are obviously going to be in for difficult times with the downturn in Asia. This will be compounded because, for years and years, we had a government that pretended Europe did not exist. It was so locked into making us part of Asia that it forgot about Europe—an area with enormous opportunity, with very high per capita earnings and a culture which, very often, because of its similarity to ours, wants our products.

I believe we must quickly look to Europe for trade opportunities. That is not to say that we should miss other opportunities. I believe there is an enormous opportunity opening up in Liberia—a country absolutely wrecked and wracked by war; a country now absolutely poverty stricken. If Australia were to get in there now with, say, a flour mill, I believe there are opportunities for us to lock them in to purchase of our wheat for perhaps 25 years. I believe that Liberia could be set up as a flour producing area. It would quickly become the source of supply to surrounding countries. The capital costs of doing this are very small; the opportunities are great. There are also many other opportunities in that part of the world which no-one in government seems to be looking at.

BREAK.PARA: The situation in North Korea is similar. North Korea, with the impending change of government in South Korea, is going to come back into the wider economy. I believe the opportunities are enormous. I believe Australia was very wise to recognise South Vietnam early, and I think we have done proportionately better than most other countries with South Vietnam. The opportunities in North Korea are even bigger. I believe the government should make entry into North Korea a real priority. It is something that I believe, because of the nature of that government, will not happen without government intervention or government support.

The truth is that unless we get a manufacturing industry going in this country again there will be no jobs for our kids; there will be no end to the current account deficit. We have seen the manufacturing industry destroyed under the Keating government, and it has to be recreated. We have to start retraining those people. This was sacrificed on the altar of free trade. Free trade rose out of the machinations of this theory of economic rationalism. It should be clearly understood that economic rationalism is not an economic theory but a political ideology; it is the ideology of big business—mainly American big business—to control world trade.

I did not actually say that; it was said by Bob Santamaria, but he is absolutely right. That is what he is about. I am about fair trade. Free trade is a nonsense. I am a great advocate of fair trade, and I believe that, as a fair trader of the world, we have enormous opportunity, but it is an opportunity that will not be able to be developed without vision and support from government. As I say, in some of these countries you are going to need a degree of government to government initiatives to pave the way.

In looking at the problems that beset Australia, unemployment is clearly a big one. I said earlier that the lack of confidence that people have in government is very destabilising. I believe that, if we were to adopt citizen initiated referenda as a policy, we could restore that confidence. People would have some confidence in the government if, at the end of the day, they could say no and have some control.

The High Court of Australia used to be subject to appeals to the Privy Council, and it was without doubt the best appellate court in the world. We removed that right of appeal to the Privy Council and within a very short time the High Court of Australia became a bunch of social engineers. I make no bones about it: the original Mabo decision was a social engineering decision and not one based on law—certainly not good law. I believe we need something like citizen initiated referenda to put some power, some control, some intellectual rigour not only into government but also into bureaucracy and the High Court of this country.

CIR as proposed by us—the policy has been put forward by Australia First—would operate in such a way that, if someone could get two per cent of the people across Australia to agree to a certain petition being put to a referendum, the government of the day would be duty bound to include that with the next election. The cost would be absolutely minimal. If that were carried by a constitutional majority—that is, the majority of people in the majority of states—it would then be incumbent upon the government to make that law. That is the only change we require to the constitution.

The concept of CIR was in the first draft of our constitution. It was taken out when politicians thought they would keep this power for themselves. The truth is that I as a politician have no more power than the general public. Power resides with the executive government. We would like to seek an amendment to the constitution—the only amendment we require. It will do far more to keep our constitution up to date than the $30 million constitutional dog's breakfast that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is promoting. Australia could become a republic under CIR, but it could happen only if the majority of people in the majority of states wanted it to happen. It could not be foisted on them, as is likely to happen under the present process.

This is a very reasonable, rational, sensible, economical way of returning power to the people. I believe it should be done. It was the policy of the Labor Party from 1907 until 1964—brought in by Billy Hughes and taken out by Donny Dunstan. We in Australia First believe that it will return power to the people in a real and positive way, and we certainly endorse it. It is interesting to note CIR are supported by some members of the government. I know that the member for Flinders (Mr Reith) was a great advocate of them. I think he was called off—probably at the behest of the National Party, who really never understood the concept.

It is said by some that CIR would lead to the tyranny of the majority. I see no evidence of that, because Australia is probably the fairest society in the world and I think the Australian public can be relied upon to make good judgments. But I say to those academics and those people who say they fear this that there is something worse, in my view, than the tyranny of the majority, and that is what we have had in Australia in recent times: the tyranny of the minority. I think that has to be taken into consideration.

Returning power to the people through CIR and doing something about employment is what this country needs. It we can achieve those things, there will be some new respect in the community for parliament. Parliament will deserve that respect. Under the present system it does not, for the reality is this: people do not exist in a democratic system today. What they have is an elected dictatorship, where people vote in the government and the government takes not a blind bit of notice of them. In my view, this simply is not good enough. We need a system whereby policies can be checked by the people. I believe the combined wisdom of the Australian people will inevitably lead to good decision making. There may be the odd mistake, but overwhelmingly I trust the Australian people and I believe their judgment will be profoundly better than we have had from government in recent years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Worth, Trish, MP

TALKER.NAME: Ms WORTH
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services)

TALK.START.PARA: —Since becoming Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services in July, I have not had as many opportunities to speak in the House as I did in the past. So I do welcome this opportunity to join the debate on the appropriation bills. In doing so, I begin by saying it is an honour to be working in the health area with specific responsibilities that impact and have real influence on people's lives.

SPEECH.PARA: As we head towards the end of this parliamentary sitting year, it is an appropriate time to highlight to the House and to my constituents a range of achievements that the Howard government can justly be proud of. On coming to office this government was faced with an enormous challenge to rebuild and restore the nation's fractured economy. Strong and decisive action was required. Having been given the opportunity by the Australian people to govern, this government has ensured that, for the first time in a decade, we no longer operate with a credit card style budget.

In fact, under the directions of the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) and the Treasurer (Mr Costello), we will be repaying over $5 billion in debt and have turned a $10 billion budget deficit into a surplus, giving the Reserve Bank the impetus to allow for five cuts in interest rates. One of the many achievements this government can be proud of is that interest rates are, at 6.5 per cent, the lowest in more than 30 years. As the Treasurer so enthusiastically stated earlier this year, home loan rates are the lowest since man stepped on the moon. He could have easily added that they are the lowest since the Beatles came to Adelaide. This is positive news for the many home owners in the electorate of Adelaide with families who, since the coalition came to government, are now saving on average $333 a month on a $100,000 mortgage—a far cry from when home loan interest rates reached 17 per cent and small business loans peaked at 22 per cent under the Hawke-Keating government.

Members might be interested to know that the hardworking taxpayers are paying $9,400 million in interest on the Beazley-Keating debt each year and that figure doubled in the last five years that Labor was in government. By the year 2000, this government will have halved that—and I take this opportunity to congratulate the Minister for Finance and Administration (Mr Fahey) on his efforts in this area.

I very much appreciate hearing from the large number of hardworking small business operators that things are beginning to look brighter in their area. This can only be good news for Adelaide. I am taking the opportunity as often as I can to communicate this good news to the wider community because I know that good news leads to confidence and therefore more jobs, which is good news for our young people.

I am pleased that the elderly members of our community will face Christmas reassured that we have listened to their concerns on our aged care policy. This issue has received a lot of attention in the parliament, the media and the wider community. This is not such a bad thing, however, because for the first time in a long time a government is prepared to address this most crucial issue of nursing home accommodation standards. In a speech I gave in the parliament in June 1994 after the release of the Gregory report, which of course was commissioned by the previous government, I said:

This report by Professor Bob Gregory . . . reveals the crisis facing Australia's nursing homes, which look predominantly after the frail aged . . . There is a need for a substantial improvement in nursing home buildings, but because of the government funding formula there is a lack of incentive to maintain a good quality of nursing home stock.

I am also on the record while in opposition of reminding the then government of the findings of the Economic Planning Advisory Council's report Australia's ageing society , when it stated that the number of aged people will rise from 1.9 million in 1991 to more than five million by the year 2051 when more than one person in five will be over the age of 65 and that adequate government resources would be required to address this situation. Again the then Labor government chose to ignore yet another serious report calling for government action.

The main aim of the changes made by the Howard government is to ensure sufficient money is in the system to provide quality care for those five per cent of us who will end up needing nursing home care. The recent announcement by the Prime Minister will relieve genuine concerns in the community while, at the same time, ensuring that more money is available to improve the standard of our nursing homes. A fair and reasonable contribution is being sought from those who can afford to make that contribution. The accommodation bond has been scrapped, a decision which guarantees that no-one will be forced to sell the family home to enter a nursing home. As the government has said all along, access to nursing homes will be based on the need for care, not capacity to pay. Places will continue to be set aside for people who cannot pay.

When a family member enters a nursing home it is a stressful time for the whole family. Improving accommodation where necessary is important. As has been put to me recently in my own electorate, why should someone leave the comfort of their own home to spend the last months of their life and to die in a dormitory? I again pay tribute to those providers in my own electorate who do provide quality care in their hostels and nursing homes.

To say that I am disappointed at the scare campaign undertaken by the members opposite is an understatement; yet this is a party who, when in government, turned its back on our elderly. The Australian Labor Party forced many senior members of our community to endure substandard accommodation and was a government that in its final years actually reduced the level of capital funding by a staggering 75 per cent. For a party that preaches access and equity, this is nothing short of disgraceful. The amount of distress and anxiety Labor has caused to many of the residents of my electorate is unacceptable. Labor has offered no solutions, other than raising taxes to fund extravagant claims. I remind the people of Adelaide that Labor will do and say anything to be elected.

As a member of this Howard government, I will continue to work hard to ensure that the needs of our elderly remain a high priority. The government is continuing to consult and listen to older people, their carers and families, the aged care industry and the broader community. I have spoken with a number of people over the last 12 months on this issue, and I will continue to pass on to the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) the concerns of the people in my electorate.

In health care the Howard government is again leading the way with its reform agenda. From 1 July this year low and middle income Australians have received financial incentives to encourage them to take out private health insurance. The program is designed to provide families with a $450 incentive, couples with a $250 incentive and individuals with a $125 incentive. As we all saw last week, the number of people registered as having taken out private health insurance has risen for the first time in seven years. It is to be hoped that that trend continues. We now have a government that encourages both the private and the public sectors to work side by side and recognises how one is interdependent on the other.

Recently the Prime Minister took up the challenge to tackle one of the biggest killers of Australia's young people—drugs. It is an issue which for too long has been swept under the carpet. The coalition has an integrated plan to get tough on drugs. The Prime Minister has committed some $87 million over three years, with the emphasis on working with state governments, parents, teachers, health professionals, and volunteer and community organisations to combat this antisocial and harmful activity. The government has committed some $43 million on intercepting illicit drugs and the remaining funds are to be allocated to school education, rehabilitation and research. I reassure the many concerned parents and young people in my electorate that this government is determined to put an end to the drug couriers who are responsible for the deaths and harmful destruction of lives of our nation's youth. My office has received a number of congratulatory calls to the government for tackling this serious issue head on.

I remind the House of the excitement of the day the Telstra shares were floated on the stock exchange—I again congratulate the Minister for Finance and Administration for the great hand, steady influence and great management he has displayed in this area— resulting from the one-third sale of the nation's telecommunications giant; another election promise delivered. With many Adelaide mums and dads purchasing shares for the first time in their lives, I am sure they are more than pleased with how Telstra is performing to date.

I can vividly recall the protests from the members opposite and their latest recruit, Cheryl Kernot, about how the selling of this particular government instrumentality was the end of the world, despite the fact that Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank were sold by Labor when they said that they would not be sold. This act of hypocrisy is well known amongst the people of Adelaide. Ninety-two per cent of Telstra's work force have taken up their employee share options; 1.1 million Australians have invested their hard-earned savings in an Australian company that has grown and will continue to grow. Labor have once again shown themselves to be out of touch with the people of Australia.

The other side of the coin is the positive capital investment in our nation's precious environment through the $1.1 billion Natural Heritage Trust. In the electorate of Adelaide projects under way include `the scrub' Aboriginal food plant trail at Kilkenny and the revegetation of the River Torrens riparian sites.

The state of South Australia will benefit greatly from the trust. In June of last year when I spoke on the Natural Heritage Trust Fund Bill , I highlighted many projects that were to commence. One of the major projects is the Murray-Darling 2001 initiative. This project has some $300 million in funding set aside to deliver major benefits in water quality and quantity provided to South Australia from the Murray‐Darling river system. As the driest state in the driest continent on earth, and as the state which relies on the Murray River for significant agricultural production and most of the drinking water for its large urban areas, including Adelaide, this project is absolutely essential.

Another vital area being addressed is the condition of our coastal and marine environments—85 per cent of Australia's population live on the coastline. The coast and clean seas initiative, with a commitment of $100 million over four years, will greatly assist in tackling the difficult environmental problems facing South Australia's coasts and seas. Ocean outfalls such as the discharge of secondary treated sewage effluent from Adelaide's treatment works and its subsequent impact on the seagrass must be addressed. I would like to take this opportunity to remind the House of what Dr John Cole, Chief Executive Officer of the Environment Management Industry Association of Australia has said:

Money, not good intentions and high rhetoric, is what is required to protect and improve our environmental resource . . . we have the scientific and technological answers, but environmental solutions cost money and the Natural Heritage Trust will provide significant amounts of money for environment investment.
It is time for real action on the environment to match real concern. The coalition government is committed to ensuring a viable and sustainable environment for our future generations.

Turning to the subject of Wik, I noted the comments of the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell). He said that the 10-point plan put forward by the Prime Minister was not enough and was not as strong as that put forward by the previous Keating government. His statements highlight the complex issues surrounding the government's Native Title Amendment Bill , which is so little understood but so important. The uncertainty surrounding native title is hurting all Australians no matter what their ethnic background. Reconciliation with indigenous Australians is important. The sooner certainty is achieved, and with the best will, the sooner true reconciliation can take place.

Despite large amounts of money being spent, the happiness, health and education of indigenous Australians are not being progressed as they should be. I have learnt from my experience in dealing with Aboriginal health and education issues that reform does not happen in a single moment or with a single gesture. It only comes with long‐term commitments aimed at practical reform and guided by a keen sense of fairness and equity.

After years of platitudes, ministerial statements and policies by the Hawke and Keating governments, the health and education of Australia's indigenous people showed no sign of improvement. The symbolism of Keating's efforts in the areas of reconciliation would have been far more credible and genuine if they had been substantiated, for example, with initiatives in rural and remote Aboriginal health that achieved real results.

Those who work and live on the land have attachments to it which are not well understood by others. Certainty for indigenous and non-indigenous Australians is important and, despite all the difficulties and complexities, cannot be run away from. The Prime Minister has personally consulted and negotiated with key groups for a fair position which while providing for certainty also seeks to achieve a workable framework for sharing and managing land into the future. Such agreements, and the mutual respect and goodwill required to achieve them, are examples of practical reconciliation at work. As the Prime Minister has said, with the passing of this legislation there can still be claims on 79 per cent of the land mass of Australia.

Land management, certainty, fairness and reconciliation are all issues to be worked on in a responsible manner. Some overly political or heated statements which have been made have not been helpful. I challenge those who know their local federal member to think about whether that person deserves the description of `racist scum'. Equally, I cannot support those who have made personal attacks on church leaders, but I do hope that church leaders consider all their flock and so work towards greater understanding of all the complexities surrounding the issues of native title.

Last week, along with my colleague the Parliamentary Secretary for Transport and Regional Development (Mr Ronaldson), I announced funding worth $1,110 million under the federal government's rail reform transition program for select projects based in South Australia. The rail reform transition program was established to help local economies adjust to the changes brought about as a result of the government's rail reform program. As someone who has been involved from the beginning as a member of the cabinet subcommittee working on rail reform, this was an exciting stage to have reached. I pay tribute to the excellent work done by the member for Hume (Mr Sharp), the former Minister for Transport and Regional Development, in achieving some very satisfactory results in rail reform and the sale of Australian National. The reforms are important for Adelaide and for South Australia.

The announcement of the funding was at the headquarters of Overseas Pharmaceutical Aid for Life, in Ridleyton. OPAL was awarded $200,000 to further develop a unique service for collecting and disposing of unwanted medicines. OPAL also distributes pharmaceuticals to lesser developed countries. This is a very worthwhile project. It will create much needed jobs, ensures an environmentally safe way of disposing of unwanted medicines, and promotes the safe removal of unwanted medicines from the home as well as coordinating donations of essential pharmaceutical products to underdeveloped countries. As the local member, I am naturally pleased with projects which promote employment in the north-west suburbs of Adelaide. As Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services, I was delighted that the safe collection and disposal of unwanted medicines was promoted, especially during National Medicines Week, another successful government initiative.

Two other companies received grants. Glen Ewin Fine Foods received $460,000 as a federal government contribution towards the establishment of new processing, packaging and warehouse facilities, which is expected to employ 16 people when complete. TAB Australia Pty Ltd received $450,000 to establish a facility in the electorate of my colleague the member for Wakefield (Mr Andrew) to manufacture sheep derived antibodies for the treatment of human diseases and other conditions such as snake and spider bites. In all, 160 long‐term sustainable jobs will have been created by the year 2000. These initiatives are a further demonstration of the federal government's commitment to addressing the adjustment needs of regional communities in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: Very briefly, I would like to speak about some of the areas for which I have responsibility as Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health and Family Services. One of those—and it is a key one—is the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, which is growing at what has been described as a self‐destructible rate if it is not kept in check. Changes made in the last budget were not slash and burn. Even with the savings, which will be approximately $500 million over four years, the scheme will still grow at $200 million per year. It is worth noting what the opposition has had to say about this and what the shadow minister said back in 1990. The opposition are criticising the TGP initiative now but in 1990 they said:

It is important to remember that four years ago this country allocated $500m from taxpayers' money to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. In the last financial year the allocation was more than $1 billion; in three years' time it will be more than $2 billion. And one can imagine how much we will be spending on subsidising the cost of drugs for our community by the turn of the century—a massive sum of money, if there is no change in the meantime.
As I have said, there has been a massive growth in the cost of pharmaceuticals, so the Government has had to take some action.
And the current shadow minister said:
Doctors should be trained to prescribe a family of drugs and not a particular brand.

We have taken that advice and looked at these issues very carefully and I am pleased to say that, having consulted widely with very well‐qualified independent experts, we have come up with a very good formula which is going to keep the PBS safe. There will be significant savings. The price premiums are 71c to $4.63, which is a long way from the horror stories which were told. Only four drugs will cost more than $3 and, more importantly, only 1.5 per cent of the 1,800 drugs listed on the PBS will have any premium at all. This has largely been achieved by the competitive pricing which has been put forward by the drug companies when they have been invited to take a competitive approach to this.

I am very grateful to the Royal Australasian College of Physicians, the Royal Australian College of General Practitioners, the AMA, the Royal Australian and New Zealand College of Psychiatrists, the Pharmacy Guild and the Pharmaceutical Society for their expert advice. (Time expired)

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill presented by Mr Costello—by leave—and read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 is a major structural reform of the way in which this country presents and runs its fiscal policy. The bill fulfils an election promise by this government to make sure that the Australian accounts are presented in a fair and honest manner and to enshrine in legislation a requirement which will govern our government and any future government as to the way in which it will present and improve its financial performance. This is the kind of reform which, when enacted, will be a permanent feature, making sure that Australia's economic policy is run better, making sure that the public is kept better informed and making sure that there is transparency in economic policy in this country.

This is the same bill that was introduced into the House of Representatives on 11 December 1996 and passed by the House of Representatives on 10 February 1997. On 28 October 1997, the Senate passed the bill with 10 amendments. These amendments were unnecessary and made aspects of the bill unworkable. A number of the amendments related to the arrangements for costing election policies during the caretaker period. They would have made the process non‐transparent by allowing the costing of unannounced policies. They would also risk turning the bureaucracy into a research centre for the opposition, inconsistent with the conventions of Westminster government.

BREAK.PARA: Another amendment sought by the Senate required a detailed report on threats to the tax system and specific means necessary to counter these threats. This would have drawn attention of tax planners to the opportunities for tax avoidance, risking larger revenue losses than would otherwise be the case. Other amendments to the charter unnecessarily complicated the operation of the bill. The amendments were a stunt. If the Labor Party, in particular, had been interested in a charter of budget honesty, it could have introduced such a bill in any one of its 13 years of government. The amendments were not agreed to by the House of Representatives—and they will not be agreed to by the House of Representatives—and the bill was returned to the Senate. The Senate again insisted on its amendments and on 19 November 1997 the House again rejected those amendments. The bill was then laid aside.

The government is reintroducing this bill because it has a mandate to enact it. It was announced before the election. It was a specific election commitment and the government has a mandate to have it introduced. The government believes that the people of Australia deserve better fiscal accountability and improved fiscal outcomes. To show its commitment to this, the government has already been complying in full with the charter's requirements.

The need for the bill is clearly demonstrated by the need for improved fiscal outcomes in Australia. There have been persistent Commonwealth budget deficits over the past 25 years. This has led to Commonwealth general government net debt ratcheting up to nearly 20 per cent of GDP by 1995‐96. This government has been repairing the fiscal mess left by the Labor Party. Before we came to office, we were told the budget was in surplus. It was not; it was in deficit to the tune of $10 billion. We inherited that problem. It became our responsibility to fix it and to put aside the mismanagement and the way in which the then government had sought to hide it.

As a result of the government's fiscal consolidation program, the budget is expected to move into surplus by 1998‐99. Continued surpluses are projected until the turn of the century. This year we are paying off debt. We expect to do that next year as well and to halve the level of Commonwealth general government debt to around 10 per cent of GDP by the turn of the century.

This bill will help to ensure that the fiscal profligacy of our predecessors is not repeated. It aims to ensure that all future governments are disciplined and that the process is transparent and accountable in operating fiscal policy. Fiscal discipline will be enhanced by requiring government fiscal policy to be formulated according to the principles of sound fiscal management. Transparency and the accountability of government will be substantially increased through improved disclosure of fiscal policy intentions and the regular reporting of information on fiscal developments.

Further, the charter will prevent future governments going to an election on the basis of outdated and misleading information on the fiscal and economic outlook. In short, this bill will ensure that at all times this government and future governments can be held accountable for their fiscal and economic policies and thereby provide the basis for a sounder economic performance for the economy as a whole, sustainable job opportunities for our people and greater accountability of government to the electors whom they serve. I would like to highlight some of the main features of the fiscal framework that will be established by the bill.
Fiscal Policy Formulation

The bill will reform fiscal policy formulation through introducing principles for the sound management of fiscal policy against which governments must develop their fiscal strategy. These principles will focus attention on a range of issues that must be addressed if fiscal policy is to be sustainable over time. The principles take account of the need to address short‐term issues, such as cyclical economic downturns, while recognising the importance of medium‐term issues such as the sustainability of government debt and national saving. The presentation of a government fiscal strategy, as required by the bill, will also increase public awareness of a govern ment's objectives and establish a benchmark for evaluating fiscal performance.
Fiscal Reporting

The charter of budget honesty will also ensure that up‐to‐date information is available so that a government's performance can be assessed against its fiscal objectives. To achieve this, the bill establishes a formal reporting structure. With each year's budget, a report will be released setting out economic and fiscal projections for the budget year and three forward years. These projections will illustrate the consequences of the adopted fiscal strategy.

A further report released midway through the financial year will update the fiscal and economic projections contained in the budget report. The details of fiscal outcomes for the just completed financial year will be presented in a report to be released within three months of the end of that financial year. In addition, an intergenerational report will be produced every five years to report on the long‐term sustainability of current fiscal policies. These reports will provide fundamental information that will allow government performance to be assessed against the objectives set out in the fiscal strategy statement. However, the bill also gives particular attention to ensuring that important fiscal information is available during the election period.

In doing that, we want to make sure that no other government in future behaves in the way in which the Labor government behaved in the March 1996 election. That government shamefully hid the true state of the books. That is why we intend to make it incumbent for a full and open report to be made about the financial state of the books at the opening of an election campaign and not to be found out by whichever government wins at the close. The only way to ensure that is done is for both houses of parliament, the parliament as a whole, to pass this legislation.

This bill requires the Secretaries to the Treasury and the Department of Finance and Administration to prepare a pre‐election report providing an updated assessment of the fiscal and economic outlook. Never again, if this legislation passes, would a government be able to go into an election without the public being aware of the current economic and fiscal situation. Never again would a government be able to practise the deception attempted by the Labor Party in the last election. Never again would that be allowed if this legislation is enacted.

In addition, the bill provides for more equal access to Treasury and Finance costings of election commitments by the government and the opposition during the caretaker period. This will allow the electorate to be better informed of the financial implications of election commitments. These provisions are fair and balanced and consistent with the principles of Westminster government. The amendments to these arrangements that had been sought by the opposition are non‐transparent and unworkable. This legislation prepared by the government is state‐of‐the‐art legislation.
Conclusion

In conclusion, the government believes that the Charter of Budget Honesty Bill 1996 represents a landmark development in the conduct of fiscal policy and reporting of fiscal outcomes. It is the kind of reform which, when enacted, will change the way in which elections are conducted; the way in which policies are implemented; the way in which future generations are brought into consideration in economic decision making; and our economic policy for the better. The bill will provide a strong impetus towards achieving better fiscal outcomes by providing greater discipline in policy formulation, regular statements of fiscal objectives and increased accountability for fiscal performance. I present the explanatory memorandum to the bill and I commend the bill to the House.

Despite much of the criticism levelled at the Public Service in general terms, the Australian Public Service does a very good job, and career public servants should be commended for their lifetime service. I am using this opportunity to raise an issue that has affected one such public servant in my electorate. I believe he has been very badly treated. The situation needs to be addressed quickly to give him the justice that I feel is appropriate. There are, sadly, incidences when public servants are not treated well by their own bureaucracy. At this point I would like to focus the attention of the House on the plight of Mr Philip Crockford, who has given some 20 years of service to Airservices Australia as an aviation firefighter.

On 26 February 1994, Mr Crockford fell off a fire truck while on duty, due to a faulty rubber tread. He fell approximately 1.3 metres to the ground, severely injuring his knee. After this accident it was found that the rubber treads on the fire vehicle did not meet Australian standards and had been produced with manufacturing faults. Airservices quickly ordered the replacement of all the steps on the trucks and notified all personnel.

Following complications with his knee, Mr Crockford had an operation in March 1995. His knee joint was found to be seriously injured and the surgeon declared him unfit for duty as a fire officer on medical grounds. He was then given light duties, which he performed until his retrenchment in September that year. Mr Crockford lodged a claim for compensation with Comcare, but they did not accept his claim. He appealed their refusal. They later accepted his claim—and this happened to occur on the same day he was officially retrenched from Airservices. Upon retrenchment, Mr Crockford received a superannuation payment of $151,068 gross. Airservices Australia assured him that this money would not in any way affect his appeal to, and compensation from, Comcare. Airservices, in fact, assured him of this in writing.

After accepting his claim, Comcare advised him that he would receive his full salary for 45 weeks and 75 per cent of his salary thereafter until the age of 65. Any medical expenses incurred because of the injury would also be covered. Mr Crockford received his usual weekly salary until January last year. In the following month or two, his weekly payments were significantly reduced from $880 to $453. This was, of course, far below the 75 per cent he had been promised.

Naturally, he appealed this steep reduction in his salary as it was contrary to the advice given to him by Comcare. He was then informed that, due to a mistake on Comcare's part from the start of the case, he had been overpaid by almost $11,000. Comcare also informed him that as he had received $151,068 in superannuation upon retrenchment and, due to an error, had initially been assessed under the wrong section of the Safety and Rehabilitation Compensation Act he was being assessed under section 19 when, according to Comcare, he should have been assessed under section 21A. Both Airservices and Comcare were at fault in this matter.

Section 19, I believe, applies to employees who are injured and therefore incapacitated for work but who are not entitled to a superannuation pension or lump sum payout. They would be in receipt of 75 per cent of their weekly salary—and this is indexed until retirement age of 65. Section 21A applies to those who are incapacitated for work but who are entitled to a superannuation pension and not a lump sum payout. In these cases, 75 per cent of weekly salary, less the employer's compulsory superannuation contribution plus interest and the normal superannuation contribution they would make if still employed in their former positions, is payable until the age of 65.

Under this new section, section 21A, $84,136, including interest, of Airservices' compulsory superannuation contributions to Mr Crockford's super over 20 years, and $14,000 paid in tax, had to be returned to Comcare. In other words, this money will be put towards his weekly payments until the age of 65 as part of his compensation. It is interesting to note that the superannuation contribution equivalent to the amount he would have had to make while employed as a fire officer grade 2 is currently being deducted from Mr Crockford's weekly payments. To a layman, this effectively means that, after 20 years of faithful service, Mr Crockford will be getting a superannuation payment of only $41,648—that is in cash—and a rollover of $10,598 at the age of 55. In effect, he will also be funding his own compensation payments to a large degree from his superannuation.

I believe it is a travesty that because of an ineffective and faulty step tread on his fire vehicle Mr Crockford suffered an injury which is costing him a 20-year career and the loss of more than $50,000 in wages and superannuation per annum. He is only 49 years of age and he dearly wants to be rehabilitated back into the work force—as Airservices had once promised it would. If Airservices is unable to re‐employ him in a suitable position, it is only just that he should be appropriately compensated.

At the time of my initial representation to the minister for industrial relations on Mr Crockford's behalf in November last year, Mr Crockford was waiting for his third hearing from the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. The minister wrote back to me in December last year and advised that Mr Crockford's case had been dismissed by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal on 19 November last year. He did not, however, elaborate on the reasons for the dismissal of his appeal. This was very disappointing. Unfortunately, we felt that, given the immovability of some of the bureaucracy and some of the regulations they have to enforce, maybe we were beating our heads against a brick wall.

But it has been recently brought to my attention that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal did not dismiss Mr Crockford's case at all. They were simply not in a position to proceed further with his case on the grounds that the matter was outside their stipulated powers. It was clearly conveyed to Mr Crockford that the Administrative Appeals Tribunal could only consider a case where an authority—Comcare in this instance—was correctly following guidelines at the time of the hearing. His appeal, however, relates to Comcare's earlier treatment of him when it was evident that Comcare did not follow the Safety Rehabilitation and Compensation Act 1988 as it should have done.

Mr Crockford had little choice but to withdraw his case. This was done so on the advice of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal. Despite the fact that his appeal to the Administrative Appeals Tribunal did not result in a determination, his efforts were not entirely in vain. Members of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal understood Mr Crockford's predicament and must have sympathised with him. It was suggested that he look up subsection 114B(5) and subsections 114D(1-5) of the SRC Act.

Subsection 114B(5) deals with the fact that any irregularities—overpayments, for instance—must be rectified within two working days by Comcare, whilst subsections 114D(1-5) make provision for Comcare to waive the debt. Comcare has certainly failed to comply with subsection 114B(5). It is very clearly stipulated in subsection 114B(5) that Comcare has two working days in which to rectify an overpayment. Comcare took much more than a couple of days to rectify their administrative error. It took them well over six months. Judging from the information that I have on hand and the treatment Mr Crockford has received to date, it is difficult not to conclude that he is being forced to pay for the mistakes and tardiness of Comcare.

As mentioned earlier, Mr Crockford is only 49 years of age. As a result of an injury suffered in no way through any fault of his own, his working lifespan has suddenly been cut short by some 16 years. This is enormously tragic for a man who has given over 20 years of service to Airservices Australia and total dedication to a job that he loved very much. As an aviation fire officer grade 2, he held an important and responsible position in the organisation. The fact that Mr Crockford had accumulated over 400 hours of sick leave at the time of the accident is indicative, I believe, of the depth of his commitment to his work and his loyalty to Airservices. He certainly did not abuse his sick leave and take time off just for the sake of it. He was very committed to his job.

Mr Crockford's 400 hours of accumulated sick leave could easily have carried him through to January 1996 on full pay. When he was retrenched in September 1995, he was effectively forced to forgo his sick leave entitlement. Had he not been in receipt of grossly inaccurate and misleading advice from both Airservices Australia and Comcare he would not have been in the unfortunate predicament that he now finds himself in.

To deny Mr Crockford justice now is to add to his tragedy—and this, in my opinion, is totally unacceptable. The government is effectively telling Australians aged over 55 that they have nine months in which to find a job and if they cannot find one in that time they will be forced to retire. . provide in full the funds earmarked in the 1995‐96 Budget to match compulsory employee contributions according to the proposed schedule.

Research done for the ASFA retirement income blueprint and by the AMP Society shows that the nine per cent superannuation guarantee contribution alone will result in a replacement income of around 28 per cent of final income after 30 years. We all remember the government's undertaking to produce a 50 per cent reduction in red tape for small business. Something like 144,000 small businesses or their tax accountants and advisers are required to complete these forms some 10 days from now. It is an onerous and virtually impossible task for those funds and for those small businesses. It represents a massive increase in small business red tape.

By way of contrast, Labor is very proud of its superannuation record. We established the comprehensive three pillars retirement income system based on government guaranteed age pensions, compulsory superannuation coverage and incentives for voluntary superannuation contributions. It was Labor which positioned superannuation to make a significant contribution to national savings over the medium term. It was Labor which extended access to superannuation benefits throughout the work force, especially to women and to part‐time workers. When we assumed office in 1983, only 40 per cent of the work force had access to superannuation. When we left office, the figure was over 90 per cent. We established the foundations for bigger retirement incomes with the superannuation guarantee. We put in place a strengthened prudential regime through the SI(S) Act which provides greater confidence that the benefits promised by superannuation will in fact be realised.

This government's shortcomings are ever more obvious, whether they be in its treatment of older Australians, in its treatment of superannuation, in its treatment of small business or in the way it approaches the Australian‐made program, having scuttled that program. We need the government to revisit some of the poor decisions that it has made concerning superannuation and the Australian‐made program. (Time expired)

The issue I want to speak about, though, relates to one of the most crushing bureaucratic systems that this country is facing and that this parliament has to deal with—the Child Support Agency. I want to describe a particular process in law for the recovery of a debt. First of all, in law to recover a debt you must prove your claim. In proving your claim you have to set out your statement of claim; the other side has a right to reply to that claim, and then the claim is justiciable in a court of law. After the court considers the merits of the particular claim comes execution, which may mean an oral examination of the debtor. It may also entail, of course, proof on oath verifying the debt is still in existence—all the way an established procedure which gives the rights to the creditor and the debtor and protects against abuse. That is the way that the courts work.

Imagine having all of that power for the benefit of one side only—that is, there is no court; there are no checks and balances; there is an administrative procedure with the enormous power to make a determination of where the merits lie—and frequently that is done with a stroke of the pen; and enormous power to execute, to make judgments of law without hearing any arguments and to make decisions that can literally destroy lives without the slightest equity attaching to the life being destroyed.

We have this in the Child Support Agency, and I want to give you some examples of that. It is important that one reflects on that, particularly those who know how the law works, to just see how we have got this powerful body which can do all these things and yet is not sufferable and not subject to the constraints of a court of law. The following example is a real one from my electorate. My constituent worked in the public service in Victoria for 10 years. In that time he was a single man, he had bought his own home, had a car and led a fairly comfortable lifestyle. He met and married a woman who brought no assets whatsoever into the marriage. The marriage was relatively short—seven years. It produced three children. He continued in his occupation. When the marriage broke down, there was a property settlement. As a result of that property settlement, my constituent no longer had a house or a decent car. Then his former wife and three children moved interstate and he, anxious to be with his children, moved interstate as well.

The question arose then about how he could negotiate a redundancy. He managed to negotiate a redundancy with the relevant public service department but an issue arose as to liability in respect of the redundancy payment as far as the Child Support Agency was concerned. A bureaucrat decided that for the purposes of child support the agency would take one third of the whole of his redundancy payment. He, not unnaturally, protested that for 10 years of the slightly longer than 17 years that he was in the public service he was not even married to the woman, so 10 years of that redundancy payment was arguably his. But the Child Support Agency—acting as judge, jury and executioner, as I said—said that 10 years would be levied to the extent of 30 per cent. So what position does he find himself in? He has no car of any substance—it is an old bomb—and he resides in rented accommodation, while his wife has a $30,000 car, her own house and recently had a breast enlargement job at his expense.

That is the sort of incredible injustice that is going on in relation to the Child Support Agency. It can interfere with orders of the court. I have two examples of that. I have a constituent who went to the Family Court and had a consent order in relation to property and maintenance—all of those things were sorted out at the consent order stage including the property settlement. Within a few days of the consent order being signed, the wife went to the Child Support Agency and the agency said, `As far as we are concerned, we are not interested in the consent order; we will make a retrospective assessment.' They made a retrospective assessment in relation to child support.

The fact of the matter is that is not the only case where they are making decisions of law on orders. There is another case where a couple had a property settlement and an undertaking was given by the husband to pay maintenance at a certain figure—an undertaking, not an order of the court—but, of course, the Child Support Agency are not interested in those sorts of legal subtleties. The property settlement was deliberately entered into so that the constituent and his wife would not be subject to the Child Support Agency. They could only not be subject to the agency if they reached an agreement whereby he gave an undertaking to the court—which was not an order of the court, and the agency has got jurisdiction only where there is an order of the court. The Child Support Agency were not interested. They said, `That is an order as far as we are concerned and we will enforce that particular order.' How do you change that? `You can change that if you want to, but you have got to go back to court to change it and you have got to pay the costs of doing so.'

They are a few examples of an absolutely deplorable system which is breaking a million families in this country, and we are not listening when we sit back and say, `Well, send the person here and send the person there and ring up the child support registrar.' Mr Roger Price, the member for Chifley, told me when he was chairing the committee that the day they had a phone‐in here on the Child Support Agency there were 100,000 hits that particular day in Parliament House. TALK.START.PARA: —You conspired with it. Look at the division record.

—The member who interjects would have to accept that that is the biggest problem. People complain that they do not get a fair hearing on their arrangements. How do we do it?
