TALK.START.PARA: —Since parliament now has a limited life expectancy, this could be my last budget speech. On this last sitting day I take the opportunity to express deep concerns about where our political and social system is going. My basic theme could be called `Politics and the retreat from reason.'

SPEECH.PARA: Since the 1980s the rise and extent of economic and social change, often caused by forces which are remote, global and impersonal, has led to a dramatic loss of confidence—both personal and collective—in the political process. Government is, at worst, seen as `the enemy' and, at best, has suffered a loss of legitimacy. I cannot remember a time when the political system has been in such low repute. I used to be proud to be a member of parliament. Now I feel uneasy to admit it.

The computer‐communications revolution, the development of a global economy and the pre‐eminence of free market economics contributed to a collapse of faith in governments, notably in the command economies of the former Soviet bloc but also in democratically elected ones. Governments might have been expected to take the lead in planning for an era of unusually rapid change but collapse of confidence in political processes had a serious impact.

At a time when technology provided a unique capacity to break down hierarchies and promote individual autonomy, citizens felt confused, marginalised and frustrated, and fear encouraged desperation. Voters complained of a leadership vacuum and a sense of being disenfranchised. This was understandable when the impact of rapid change and globalisation—its pluses and minuses—were never explained to them. Workers suffered from change fatigue. In 1996 a deep sense of accumulated grievance contributed to Labor's massive defeat.

In the 1980s rational absolutists in the West pushed an economic agenda which was rarely debated or explained. In The Doubter's Companion John Ralston Saul praises the Neapolitan historiographer Giambattista Vico (1688‐1744) for his criticism of rational absolutism:
the vaunting of judgment without context; that is, of rational abstractions applied piecemeal without reference to reality or history.

Thus the advocates of economic rationalism proclaimed it as a demonstration of natural law—something self‐evident and beyond question, like physics—and its critics as obscurantists. Social factors, including community values, were grossly discounted.

The term `economic rationalism' may be an Australian coinage. Dr Bruce Moore in the new Australian Concise Oxford Dictionary thinks it is. Every value was assumed to have a dollar equivalent. If not, it was disregarded. The bottom line became paramount in policy making. Economics displaced the concept of the public good. Changes were rarely explained to voters. Indeed, they were sometimes told the contrary: for example, that the Commonwealth Bank and Qantas would not be sold. Elites reached a consensus on a major policy and then imposed it top down. The political process was compliant. Then came the voter backlash. As Isaac Newton proposed in his Third Law of Motion, `To every action is always opposed an equal reaction.'

The last 15 years have been marked by the revival, emergence or dominance of a number of related factors or assumptions that have become central to the conventional wisdom. They can be linked under the heading of `the retreat from reason'. Some are elitist, even more are populist and the rest are part of the system.
Under the elitist heading, there are seven items.
1. The assumption that all values have a dollar equivalent. This is called `the bottom line.'
2. The privatisation of knowledge and research.
3. Downsizing of government.
4. Globalisation.
5. Top‐down decision making, bypassing the political process.
6. The corporatist model of rule, with `governance' as the prevailing cliche.
7. Promoting the economic above the social.
Under the populist heading, there are twelve items.

BREAK.PARA: 1. Attacking elites and technical or economic expertise.
2. Fantasising the past: the `cheer squad' view of history, in opposition to the `black armband' view. It is a revival of the politics of nostalgia.
3. Promoting of simple explanations for complex phenomena, as a reassurance against feelings of insecurity.
4. Reacting against globalisation: a return to the false security of regarding Australia as a bounded unit.
5. Reviving of the idea of `White Australia against the Asian hordes'.
6. Opposing native title and the High Court's Wik judgment.
7. Confusing democracy and populism.
8. Confusing equality and uniformity—a redefinition of fairness.
9. Demonising the weak and accommodating the strong.
10. Taking a punitive attitude to the unemployed.
11. Scapegoating.
12. Attacking the undefined concept of political correctness in gender, race and related issues.
There are five systemic changes.

1. Commitment to traditional reliance on `comparative advantage'—that is, the idea that all wealth comes out of the land—and rejection of `competitive advantage', the important distinction made by Harvard's Michael Porter, illustrated by Australia's failures in innovation and industry policy and its deep international isolation on greenhouse issues.
2. Confusion between long‐term and short‐term factors.

3. The isolation of the ABC and Radio Australia and the vulnerability of the Fairfax papers, as the distinction between information and entertainment is blurred. Those in power promote this isolation, expecting populist approval.

4. Lack of serious debate or discussion on major issues of economics, history, politics and culture. There are many examples of this: tariffs, the GST, Manning Clark, native title and, earlier, the collapse of the Soviet system, and the Gulf War.
5. The disappearance of the public intellectual. How many of them are under 50?

Globalisation appears to be unstoppable, but it poses serious threats to national political, economic and technological autonomy. It may make democracy irrelevant; it certainly contributes to the sense of powerlessness of ordinary citizens. My friend Kimon Valaskakis, now the Canadian Ambassador to the OECD, argues that at present 200 economic entities rule the world: 160 of them are corporations; only 40 are nation states. Who, he asks—perhaps the Attorney-General (Mr Williams), who is at the table, might respond—legislates for the 200, or can legislate? We have, he says, one world, but `one world without government'.

The market system has no rules and is, in the end, a basic threat to democracy. In a democracy, one person equals one vote; in the market system, $1,000 equals 1,000 votes. National autonomy is also threatened by three movements: upwards towards supranational entities such as the EU; sideways toward bilateral arrangements or links with non-government organisations, NGOs, or international government organisations, IGOs; or downwards towards regionalism—autonomy for Scotland or Catalonia, for example.

With the ending of the Cold War, there is a search for enemies within, and the rise of conspiracy theories. In the US in 1990, quite suddenly, communists ceased to be the main enemy and were replaced by practitioners of `political correctness'. Democracy and populism are confused, with appeals to emotion and fear, refusal to examine evidence or provide analysis. Propaganda displaces information, with growing emphasis on what Norman Davies—in his recent book entitled Europe: A History—calls the rule of simplification, `reducing all data to a simple confrontation between "Good and Bad", "Friend and Foe"'; and the rule of disfiguration, `discrediting the opposition by crude smears and parodies'.

Australia suffers from leadership failure and lack of vision. In my brief tribute in the House to Isaiah Berlin on 24 November, I referred to his 1953 book The Hedgehog and the Fox, where he took up the words of the Greek poet Archilochus: `The fox knows many things and the hedgehog one big thing.' Berlin was a fox, so are Whitlam, Evans, Hawke, Keating and Beazley—and, in my own limited way, I suppose, myself. Each reacted to new experiences and insights by taking them up and adapting them.
In this analysis, the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) is the classic hedgehog. The New Columbia Encyclopedia states:
When frightened a hedgehog rolls itself into a tight ball with its spines pointing outward; when rolled up it is invulnerable to almost any predator.

The Prime Minister reacts like a hedgehog to external challenge in areas that he feels uncomfortable about, whether it is Wik, global climate change, what he calls, but does not define, `political correctness', or confronting darker elements of our history. The one exception where he showed decisive leadership qualities was in gun control, an area where he received total support from the opposition and Democrats. I was also grateful for his support for Australia's continued membership of UNESCO.

At a time of psychological stress in the community, there is a risk that major issues in economics and history will not be given serious debate, and this may lead to grossly oversimplified stereotyping. The past can be fantasised both by advocates of the cheer squad or what is attacked as the `black armband' view.

Some nations have adopted the position of refusing to recognise, let alone respond to, unpleasant aspects in the national record, calling it a `black armband' view of history. Switzerland was in denial about its close collaboration with Nazi Germany and the disposal of Jewish gold; Japan censored, and indeed still censors, textbooks which expose atrocities in China and Japan; France suffered collective amnesia about the wartime occupation record until Jacques Chirac let in some light in 1995. This suggests a failure of nerve and compassion and the loss of a moral base for government.

In Australia, the idea of a national apology to Aborigines because of past cruelties and misjudgments led to strong government resistance and a complete failure of empathy. There was a confusion between guilt and shame, two very different concepts. The converse of guilt is innocence; the converse of shame is pride.

The Prime Minister has attacked the habit of introspection; that is, examining one's own thoughts. As you can see, a very dangerous practice! An uneasiness about close or critical scrutiny of Australian history or our own political processes seems to be closely related to attacks on the independence and adequate funding of the ABC and well‐publicised concern that the Fairfax papers were `out of control' and `too liberal', needing the discipline of a more profit oriented ownership.

The political backlash to the dramatic changes of the 1980s was a long time coming, but the swing against Labor in the March 1996 election was severe. One of the most important, but unrecognised, themes of the One Nation Party is the rejection of intellectual leadership, elitism and professional knowledge. The honourable member for Oxley (Ms Hanson) has coined a great phase: if she wants to dismiss evidence or statistics, she says, `That's just a book fact.' Department of immigration statistics on Asian migration? Only book facts. 1996 census returns on Australian residents of Asian origin? More book facts.

The Hanson phenomenon feeds on a deep sense of alienation, with its appeal to the politics of nostalgia, reassurance, and the world of childhood and simplicity, offering simple explanations for complex phenomena. She is a symptom, not a cause. The honourable member for Oxley echoes the world, with some honourable exceptions, of talkback radio. Words can be used as bullets and they can cause instant damage—damage that can take years to be repaired. It is a gross misuse of the principle of free speech to insist on the right to attack but not to accept accountability for damage done. Target groups are demonised, ignorance is regarded as a strength, questions are answered with slogans or opportunistic appeals to patriotism. The right of free speech is a very precious natural right and must be preserved at all costs. However, the right to be taken seriously has to be earned.

The government's response to the challenge of global warming and the issues being raised right now at the Kyoto conference have been profoundly depressing. While Europe, the US and Japan are all agreed on containing emission standards, Australia engages in special pleading. We say that, if we were expecting CO2 emission increases of 28 per cent by the year 2010, and are now proposing to cut it down to 18 per cent, that should be considered as a significant reduction.

The saddest thing is the failure of the government to grasp that the whole pattern of energy use world wide is likely to change dramatically in the next 20 years. Australia is putting most of its money on coal because we are still bemused by the concept of comparative advantage—that if we did not have the coal, where would we be? We take no interest in energy efficiency because we see that as being against the national interest. Energy waste? Now that is a different matter. We'll drink to that. We are in grave danger of making the same mistake that Telecom made years ago, when communications providers were moving to optical fibre—that is, internationally—which is a silica based technology. Australia's response was to say, `We have no comparative natural advantage in silica, but we do have it in copper. Let's concentrate on coaxial copper cables.'

When I talk to people in industry about the huge opportunities which will arise in energy efficient devices over the next 20 years, I am often told, `Why don't we leave it to the Swedes? They can do that. We'll concentrate on the coal; they can concentrate on energy efficiency.' How extraordinary that, when ABARE was doing its computer modelling for the government about alleged `worst case' scenarios if we adopted international greenhouse gas abatement targets, only organisations which paid an up-front fee of $50,000 were allowed to help design the model. Not surprisingly, the coal industry was up front; the environment movement was absolutely nowhere.

Universities and other research bodies, notably CSIRO, are now increasingly depend ent on market forces. If knowledge did not produce a product, what was its use? Lawyers, doctors, dentists, accountants, and MBAs were assumed to have a value. But linguists, historians, philosophers, classicists, musicologists, archaeologists, theologians? Forget it. The retreat of the academies, fearful of offending sponsors and perhaps unsure of their own non-economic value, has seriously diminished the quality of debate in Australia. On paper we have never been so well educated. But is this reflected in the quality of our public discourse?

This phenomenon that I have been talking about, the retreat from reason, is not confined to Australia. In the US, powerful, rich and well educated, a significant minority repudiated the open society, mainstream politics and sceptical detachment, leading to the revival of fundamentalism and a growing conviction that government itself was the enemy. This led to what has been called `the revenge of the powerless'. It is striking how many popular films and television series show the US government acting brutally and deceptively against the interests of its citizens—The Rock, Mission: Impossible, The X-Files, Millennium and Dark Skies all illustrate that view.

California, oddly, links very high levels of formal education with extraordinary credulity and suggestibility, illustrated by the mass suicide of members of the Heaven's Gate cult at the time that the Hale-Bopp comet appeared. The Pathfinder landing on Mars coincided with the 50th anniversary of the alleged Roswell, New Mexico, invasion by aliens. To many US citizens, Roswell may have seemed more real.

Czech President, Vaclav Havel, has referred to a `loss of transcendence', the decline of an overarching belief system which makes sense of the contemporary world, contributing to the rise of cults committed to a conspiratorial or apocalyptic view, with cult members seeing themselves as victims, leading to an absolute commitment to a cause or leader of the world, all too often including the use of killing and terror as ideological instruments.

I hope that parliament and the whole political process, including the parties, will play a central role in promoting the ethos of democ racy. However, a revival of the political process will not just depend on parties, parliaments and voting. It will require more use of intermediate bodies, including churches, trade unions, environmentalists and business groups; a fearless judiciary; stronger and more diverse media and research communities; and the encouragement of knowledge, analysis, scepticism, transparency, curiosity and understanding. A revolution in education will be needed to redefine values, as well as a critical spirit, with heavier emphasis on history, philosophy, English and foreign languages. The election of a Beazley Labor government in 1998 or 1999 will be an essential first step.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to the contribution on the appropriation bills from the member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). I have a keen interest in some of the issues, particularly when he talked about companies involved in trade around the world. I, too, have some concerns about that. But I differ quite strongly when he takes issue with the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) about native title. Native title is a very complex issue. If some of the people who have entered into the debate in this parliament bothered to read the evidence in the Hansard of the Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, they would start to see some of the concerns that Aboriginal people have with the 1993 act and some of the problems that have exhibited themselves since that time.

SPEECH.PARA: For instance, many Aboriginal people are concerned about the threshold test. They are concerned about people who are claiming land. They are in the situation where Aboriginal people they call outsiders, particularly, for instance, from Brisbane, are claiming land in Far North Queensland that traditional people have lived on for many years and believe to be their land. Some of these things need to be looked at very closely to see that this act is not working and is causing divisions even within the Aboriginal community.

The area of title is very complex. There are many leaders in the Aboriginal community, particularly the more prominent ones, who are preferring to fight these things through the courts. The reason they are doing that is they believe they will somehow get a greater win out of this. When you talk to prominent legal people who have come before the committee and asked questions, they say that if this is to be done by case law it can take 30 years to 50 years to try to clarify some of the issues that have been raised by the High Court decision. I do not think this country can afford to wait 30 to 50 years to clarify some of this law. It will not do anyone in this country any good, including Aboriginal people. So there is a necessity to try to clarify some of this law. This particular amendment has been moved in the native title debate:
5A After section 11
Insert:
11A Extinguishment of native title on freehold land.
2(b) where a grant of land registered as freehold title is made by the Crown in any capacity to the Crown, or to a statutory authority of the Crown, in any capacity . . .

That amendment is saying that, if that land had been registered as freehold by the Crown, extinguishment of native title would not be necessarily granted. If we look very closely at some of the developments around the country, we can see the danger of that position. For instance, a situation has been brought to my attention of a very major development in Brisbane. Admiralty Towers Stage II development is a 36-storey, 189 unit tower which was completed in 1997. It comprises 106 two‐bedroom units, 77 three‐bedroom units, and eight penthouse units, plus basement parking for 260 cars over three levels. The building also includes two pools and gymnasium and recreation areas—one in the high rise and one in the low rise sections. Stage I of the development, on property 27, was completed towards the end of 1995. The combined total project cost was $155 million—a very major development.

The title, if we look very closely at it, is rather interesting. Properties 24 and 27—then defined differently—giving a total site area of approximately 5,620 square metres, together with map 19 property 5, were bought for $11,700,000 in June 1987 by Seymour Developments. Properties 24 and 27, as they were then defined, reverted to the Crown in January 1988. A special lease was issued to Ariadne subsidiary Seymour Developments Pty Ltd, which later changed its name to Adnam Pty Ltd. This is a lease which was reverted to the Crown and then was leased back to the developer, even though it supposedly was bought under freehold conditions.

In 1994, Seymour CBD entered into a new special lease of this property together with the area shown on the map. This leasehold was transferred to Seymour (Admiralty Towers) Pty Ltd in March 1995. Only part of the transfer was officially recorded, being $5,200,000 for lot 902. The freehold of this property was to have been acquired for $6,500,000 on completion of stage II of the apartment tower. This shows just how complex some of these areas are. When we get people trying to fiddle with a complex issue that has been gone through very carefully by the government to see that some of these issues can be clarified it really does show the problems that can arise.

The same situation occurred in New South Wales. Something like $80 million has been expended and we have had one claim settled. I will go through that claim fairly carefully because the House should be interested in what happened there. I happened to be Minister for Lands in New South Wales at the time that the first approaches were made by the local council to develop that particular piece of Crown land. They wanted me to supply to the council free of charge Crown land so they could develop it for residential. I naturally said no, because the land belonged to the state. I said that I would sell it to them for the market value at the time. They replied that they could not afford that total value.

So we subsequently entered into an agreement that the land would be supplied by the state, the local council would develop it and, after development, the profits that were made would be shared by the state and the local council. What happened was the circumstances of history: the 1994 act intervened before the land had been converted from crown land to freehold; the council had developed part of the land and sold off the blocks; and people had built houses and units on that particular land. Technically, they did not own the land because it had not been converted to freehold and had been claimed by the Aboriginal people under the act.

We say this was a settlement, but it really was not a settlement. Some people tend to criticise the Aboriginal people for the fact that it was sold very quickly. I have to say to you: it does not matter which government was in power in New South Wales, that had to be dealt with because it was a problem between the jurisdictions of the state government and the law that had been passed by the federal government. I do not classify that as a settlement. Undoubtedly, negotiations took place, but really the whole issue had to be resolved because of the fact that those people had claimed the land, rightly, under the federal act, yet the land had been sold to people who built houses and units on it.

That is where you have to be very careful in this whole area when you start to move amendments—politically based many of them—and not understand the full ramifications of what is going on here. This is a very difficult process. I think it has to be treated as such in this parliament.

BREAK.PARA: I would also like to talk, under Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1997‐98 , about some forest issues in New South Wales, particularly the federal government's involvement in the national forest policy and the negotiations that are taking place at the present time under forestry. As the honourable member at the table, the honourable member for Reid (Mr Laurie Ferguson), would understand, I have had a longstanding interest in forestry from my involvement in the New South Wales parliament. I think I do understand it a little bit.

The facts are that, with all the rhetoric that is being put forward at the present time about a better, a more value adding and a more competitive forest industry in Australia, what we are seeing—particularly in New South Wales—is the closing down of the forest industry. There is no doubt that the state government of the day, the Carr government at present, is using the national forest policy to do that. If you look very closely at the actions and procedures that were put in place by the previous Labor government in Canberra—and carried on by this government—for a national forest policy and adequate reserves being put in place, the whole area is being distorted.

Bob Carr has made promises that he is going to go out there and declare wilderness areas and national parks regardless. The fact is that he is not taking into consideration some of the key points in the national forest policy and, in particular, the socioeconomic effects on small regional centres that the policy is going to have if he continues down this track.

The interim forest policy was such that areas would be set aside to be investigated, that we would have a close look at the science involved to decide whether the areas were needed to be set aside for those reasons—because we were saying in the national forest policy that we should endeavour to preserve 15 per cent of species and that areas of special significance should be set aside. I do not think anyone had any problems with that, particularly under the guidelines at that time when we were looking at larger areas— we were looking at five or six areas across Australia.

But what has happened is that, because the greenies have absolute control of the New South Wales government, these areas have now been split up into smaller areas. They are ignoring the reserves that are already in place; they are ignoring reserves of species that are already there. The whole process has been distorted to the extent that I believe on the far north coast of New South Wales, where my electorate of Page is, we could have 60 per cent of the forest resource locked up under these plans.

That has severe repercussions for small country towns. Areas up on the Queensland border like Woodenbong, Urbenville and Bonalbo—small country villages with a few hundred people in them—depend exclusively on forest industries and grazing. If this process is allowed to continue, then we will see the demise of those particular towns. I do not think that is what we need in Australia, particularly when we are importing $3 billion worth of forest products into this country. It is an absolute disgrace that we are allowing this to continue.

There is no doubt in my mind that we have to draw Bob Carr back to the national forest policy. We have to say to him that we are not going to continue to go down this track, that we are going to take into account the socioeconomic effects of these policies. The Prime Minister has clearly said, after a number of members of this government made representations to him, that if the 15 per cent of pre-1750 species was going to have an effect on small communities, then he believed it should be in some way amended to show that these people would not be destroyed by these policies.

The problem with all of this is that the whole process is being developed on a lie—a lie that has been peddled extensively by the environment movement; a lie that always seems to curry favour with the media. But the fact is that Australian forests today are probably better forests than they were when Europeans first came to this country. When you talk about the 15 per cent of 1750, we have no documentation of what the forests were in 1750. But if you go extensively through the journals of the old explorers, almost universally you will find the explorers talking about open woodland.

Many of the forests we have today did not exist. In fact, the pilliga scrub, which has been in the news in the last two days because of the severe fires, did not exist before Europeans—it was open grassland. The only reason the top end of the Clarence, where the famous Yugilbar station, a big cattle station, used to stand, was settled was that it was open grassland. It was open grassland because Aborigines used fire regularly and extensively and the trees did not grow in those areas—they were burnt at a very young age and did not exist.

The first explorers up the Hunter River reported seeing grasslands for 20 miles each side of the river. They are not the types of forest that the greenies are now telling us existed across Australia. I think we have to get to some of the facts. Our country's foresters were very proud scientists. Undoubtedly mistakes had been made in the past—of course there had—but these people were very efficient managers of the forests and they could provide a resource on a sustainable basis.

We have heard time and again right throughout this debate that we are closing down these forests because of overcutting of forests. The government and particularly the greenies like to accuse the previous New South Wales coalition government, of which I was the minister responsible for forests, of overcutting the forests, but they neglect to say they made that assessment after another national park was declared. A percentage of the area available to the industry has been locked away. They look at the Crown quotas for timber and say, `This is terrible because you have this Crown quota but you now do not have the resource to provide it.' Of course we do not—because it has been locked away. That is the great lie that gets peddled right across the country.

The people of Australia have to start waking up to this fact because it is having very severe effects on our national economy. As I mentioned earlier, $3 billion worth of product is imported into this country and our country is selling something like $700,000 worth of product. So there is a huge deficit in forest products in this country—and there need not be.

Our plantations are not the panacea. The greenies like to paint them as being the ultimate answer because it sounds sexy to the city. They say, `You don't have to cut down the forests. You can grow plantations.' I challenge anyone to get into an aeroplane at Eden and look under them as they fly to Coolangatta. They will see very little land available on which forests can be planted. Don't tell me that knocking down the forests that are already there to grow plantations will be allowed, because that is not going to happen.

When I was a minister in the New South Wales government I did a study on this subject, and I have to say the policy is flawed. There is no doubt that plantations can augment the natural resource we have—and they should—but land on which we could grow forests is not there. Some greenies have the audacity to say we should grow them at Moree. Why do you think trees do not grow there at present? Because the rainfall and climate are just not suitable for growing them in that area.

The problem we have with this plantation policy is that, first of all, it takes 15 years to get the first thinnings. Who has the money to carry on with no cashflow for 15 years? Then of course we have to find something to use the thinnings for. They are not good for milling. They are too small. There needs to be a chip or pulp industry. But the greenies say we cannot have that. So how do we get this resource up to mill log size? Even if we do—as we have seen at the APM plantation at Coffs Harbour which was planted by private industry for the pulp industry—there are koalas in the plantations.

The New South Wales government have not yet come up with legislation—and they have been promising it for some time—that can adequately protect investment in plantations. The absence of a policy that can adequately protect an investment means we will not get any. Obviously people have seen exactly what has happened in this debate in the past.

I am also concerned about the FISAP process that is being developed in New South Wales. This process has been put in place to retrain and relocate workers and also to help industry either get out of the industry—and that is an admission in itself—or upgrade some of those processes. There seems to be a divide and conquer attitude. People are being forced out of the industry with no compensation. Workers are being forced out of the industry with no compensation. A few people are gaining, but quite a number of people are losing. Quite frankly, I think the whole process is flawed in the way it is being managed. I think the New South Wales government need to look very closely at that process because it will come back and bite them.

There has been no research into what value adding there should be. In New South Wales everyone seems to have said, `There is a pot of gold out there being supplied by both the federal and state governments. Let's go out and dip our fingers into it.' So everyone is value adding in the same way and there is a surplus of that particular product on the market at present. No-one has done the research to see whether there will be a market for that product. Now we see that one of the major mills at Walcha, New South Wales, Fennings, which has been a long time player in this industry, is about to close. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —The appropriation bills that we are debating tonight give us the opportunity to look at expenditure that the government is proposing in a number of specific areas. Tonight I want to talk about industry policy and also to make a few remarks about small business. In the first instance, industry policy or the lack thereof coming from the government is reflected by the fact that, after several inquiries and after many months of deliberation at cabinet level, it is only going to be next Monday, after the parliament rises for three months, that we will see the government announce its response to those industry reports and bring down some semblance of an industry policy.

SPEECH.PARA: I was staggered last week, when the Minister for Industry, Science and Tourism (Mr Moore) was asked a question about the steel industry and the future of a report that had been done by a bipartisan committee on the steel industry, that he remarked that he had no intention of responding to it. As a representative of the Illawarra and of the steel industry in this nation, I could not believe his response. It says plenty about the qualities of the particular member who occupies the position of minister for industry in this country.

Quite frankly, if there is one glaring omission in this government's approach to looking at the ways in which the unemployment rate can be brought down—a glaring omission that has been in place for all the 20 to 21 months that they have been in government—it is their failure to address an industry policy; it is their failure to address a manufacturing policy; and it is their failure to address the difficulties in the steel industry in this country.

Much has been said about Newcastle and, yes, it is true that BHP have taken a decision that they will no longer manufacture steel in Newcastle in about two years time. But that does not mean that BHP are not going to have a future in Newcastle, because they are. Steel products such as wire, rod and bar will continue to be manufactured in Newcastle. Some 500‐odd employees will still have jobs in that city. But, of course, it will not replace those 2,000 to 3,000 other jobs that will be lost directly because steel will no longer be manufactured there.

Can I just share this with the House: some two weeks before BHP made their announcement about Newcastle, the general manager of the Port Kembla steelworks gathered all the community leaders of the Illawarra in the Church of Christ hall in Wollongong—and there was some symbolism about that, I think—to tell us that the steel industry in the Illawarra was in for another bout of rationalisation. The term `rationalisation' is code for further unemployment of steel workers. As we have now seen through BHP's announcements, there has been rationalisation of not only those on the shop floor—many of whom have been replaced by technology anyway—but also of middle management and technical people.

What we have seen in the steel industry in Wollongong is that, from 1983, a steel industry work force directly employed by BHP of some 26,000 people has shrunk to what it is today—6,800. On the estimates given by BHP, a shrinkage of a further 2,000 in the coming 12 to 18 months is a distinct possibility. Productivity is up, yes; investment in technology is through the roof, yes—and I commend BHP for doing that. But I would also point out that BHP striving to achieve an output of 1,000 tonnes per man per year comes with a cost. That cost is the employment of people in Wollongong and, more broadly, in the Illawarra region. The downstream effect that that has is also quite significant.

When these sorts of issues were brought to the attention of the minister for industry last year—when people were talking about the future of Newcastle and whether it would survive; when people were talking about Whyalla; when people were talking about the new steel production capacity in Western Australia—it was the Labor Party that said strategic intervention may well be necessary in the steel industry again to develop a second steel industry plan, such as the one that we developed within 100 days of coming to government in 1983. That steel industry plan in 1983 actually saved the steel industry in this country. Many people have forgotten that that is the case. Many people have forgotten that it was a tripartite arrangement between the government, who played a very small role, the union movement and management in saving the steel industry. The simple fact was that BHP were quite happy to continue with minerals, oil, gas and overseas developments and to walk away from steel production at the time.

BREAK.PARA: We have to give consideration to the fact that we are again faced with retrenchments in the steel industry. We are faced with smaller operations, starting with mini‐mills in different parts of Australia, that are largely geared up for local consumption. After these concerns were brought to the attention of the minister, the government finally—dragged kicking and screaming by BHP, the unions and the Labor Party—decided to do something about it and asked a bipartisan committee of this place to examine the steel industry. That report was produced with the assistance of the minister's own department and officials and was given to him some months ago. The minister's response to that report, when asked about it last week in the parliament, was to tell the people of Newcastle, Wollongong and Whyalla that he had no intention of responding to it.

We shake our heads in Wollongong about the attitude that this government displays to our region. We shake our heads at the fact that we can see that within 20 months of government the Liberal Party has shut down an Immigration office in Wollongong, where there are over 80 ethnic nationalities represented. In an area where close to 50 of people come from overseas countries and are of a non‐English speaking background, they shut an Immigration office down! They have got the Commonwealth office block up for sale, like most other things. They have obliterated the CES and DEETYA and the other organisations which provided real assistance to people in the Illawarra. The Medicare office in Corrimal, which is opposite my electorate office, shut down on 7 November. The one in the electorate of my friend and colleague the member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) shut down at the same time, leaving two Medicare offices now for the entire Wollongong area. This is the contempt which this government has for people of the Illawarra. What has been their sin? They have returned Labor members to the federal parliament and to the state parliament. That is the sin of the people of the Illawarra.

I return to industry policy. As we know, on Monday the minister—or the Prime Minister (Mr Howard)—is intent on announcing the government's response to the Mortimer committee report and a number of others in respect of industry policy. A few strategic leaks have occurred over the last couple of days. One is in the Daily Telegraph of Thursday, 4 December under the headline `Steel City hits back'. I thought, `You beaut, they are talking about Wollongong.' But, alas, it was not; it was Newcastle. Under the headline it says, `Duty free plan to create 2,000 jobs.' And the article talks about this concept that has been pushed for some time to give, as is explained in this article, `a first industrial estate in which factories making goods for export won't pay duty on imported components'. It is this trade free or free trade zone that people have been talking about.
Mrs De‐Anne Kelly interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable members that have had some experience in this place—unlike the member for Dawson—would recognise that places such as the Northern Territory and Darwin, in particular, experienced an approach to industry policy very similar to the one that is being advocated here.

BREAK.PARA: If it is true that as part of the industry statement on Monday, the Prime Minister or the minister for industry—it is actually the Prime Minister according to this report—is going to respond to the Mortimer review, the Goldsworthy report and a number of other inquiries that have been undertaken into industry policy, and if indeed they are going to announce this concept of a trade free zone or some import duty relaxation zone for the city of Newcastle, then, if that announcement is made on Monday and this becomes part of the policy of this government to ensure that those sorts of zones will be created around Australia, Illawarra is No. 2 on Tuesday. And I suspect Geelong will be No. 3 on Wednesday. I suspect that western Sydney will come along on Thursday. I suspect that western Melbourne will come along on Friday, and on and on it will go.

I hope that that is right. I hope that there will be some incentives provided to industry in this country. I would hope that the people that have been decimated by the policies of this government already in the Illawarra will get some benefit for some industry policy and a bit of leadership out of this minister for industry because, when he is asked questions in this place, it is all he can do to struggle from his seat to get to the microphone to turn around and say nothing. That is the way he treats people with legitimate questions in this place.

But it does not stop there. Another issue that has been brought to my attention in respect of the combined areas of small business—and I am delighted to see the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) here—and industry policy relates to the issue of the Australian Made campaign and also to the idea of origin labelling that has been brought forward by the Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs (Mr Truss). I have received, as have my colleague the member for Wills (Mr Kelvin Thomson) and my colleague the member for Hotham (Mr Crean), some considerable correspondence from Mr Kevin Chambers, who is the Managing Director of Kevron Plastics Pty Ltd.

When you start to read this letter and start to understand some of the concerns he has, you have to stop to think that he has got a few points, given the fact that he also specifies that he is a long‐term Liberal voter and that he is particularly concerned about the way in which the use of the Australian Made logo has now fallen into disrepute and the fact that the licensing arrangement, which is operational in respect of that Australian Made logo, is also under question as to what its future is going to be. This is the case because, for a measly $2 million a year, the Howard government has cut funding for the Australian Made campaign.

All these people like the member for Dawson and others on the other side go around Australia saying, `We must have Australian Made. We must look after Australian producers.' She sits up there in cockies corner and then sells out the sugar industry. She sells out the tourism industry with the reef tax. On and on it goes. Then she says, `Hang on, I support Australian jobs and I support Australian manufacturers.' And here is a case in point: a lousy $2 million a year and it was cut; and the Australian Made campaign fell over.

As Mr Chambers points out in his letter to me, he actually had the opportunity to raise this with the Minister for Small Business and Workplace Relations recently at a breakfast that he attended in Melbourne. A product had come in with Made in Australia labelling on it, but on the inside it showed it was made in India. Mr Chambers, who has been running a bit of a campaign on this in Melbourne, decided he would raise it with the Minister for Small Business and Workplace Relations. He said that he showed it to Mr Reith but that unfortunately he, the minister, had expressed little interest in taking the matter further. He said that when the new Minister for Customs and Consumer Affairs, Mr Truss, was asked about this on a radio interview he said he would look into it a little further. But then he got on to talk about origin labelling and said that by the end of this year—that is, 1997—there would be some announcements made about that. Mr Chambers has also written in the National Business Bulletin of December 1997 about this issue.

The whole point of the comments being made is that under the concept of Australian Made, encouraging people to buy Australian products to give our kids a job—and we always know that people in this place on both sides of the chamber like to say, `Buy the kids a job and get the unemployed young people off the dole and into something'—for a measly $2 million this thing could have been given further legs. And it has not. What has happened now is that there are something like 2,000 licensees with this product. Everybody knows what it is: a little green triangle with a yellow kangaroo in the middle. It is a terrific symbol. I remember we started the program. Little badges were handed out, and people on both sides of the chamber were running around with these little badges and promoting Australian Made all over their electorate. All of a sudden, the government changes; you mob come in and say, `This is not a very good idea. Two million dollars: we will save that in the budget.'

TALK.START.PARA: —Didn't give them a cent.

—Not one cent, as my colleague the member for Brisbane says. And so it is gone. Yet all these people, these 2,000 licensees, genuine small businesses and large businesses who are accredited because they go through a testing procedure and are given this licence to advertise Australian Made product—there is a check made on them and the ACCC is given responsibility under the Trade Practices Act to ensure that those products are Australian made—do not know where they are anymore. The licensees are in limbo. They are in limbo because the Howard government, for the want of saving a couple of bucks here and there, decided that the Australian Made campaign was not worth the effort. ACCI, a private organisation subsequently given the responsibility for running this particular program, again is not forthcoming with funding for it or indeed any concept as to how it is to work in the future.

BREAK.PARA: I simply reiterate what I said earlier. Here you have a classic small business person, a classic, as he describes himself `Liberal Party voting small business person', who is disgusted with the attitude of the incumbent government in their approach to an Australian Made campaign that he has been championing. He has been championing it because he is a manufacturer himself—a small businessman who wants to get on, make Australian made products, be proud of it being made in Australia and giving kids a job, as the slogan went. It has not happened.

What this demonstrates is the fact that this is a mean‐spirited, penny‐pinching government that does not care for the ordinary people of Australia, the people that the Prime Minister talks about as being mainstream Australians. He does not care that people who are part of his own constituency now are saying that this government has lost the plot. In industry policy, in nursing home policy—in any policy you care to name—this is a government that has lost the plot. It is regrettable that a government, having succeeded in the election to the extent that it did, has squandered an opportunity in 20 months. To be at the stage that this government is, is extraordinary. I have been in this place only 13 years, but I have studied politics for a lot longer.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, you learned it all from the New South Wales Right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALKER.NAME: Dr KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the amendments be disagreed to.

The government has no alternative but to reject the Senate amendments to the Public Service Bill 1997 , the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997 and the Parliamentary Service Bill 1997 . I am deeply disappointed at the actions of the Senate. Significant legislative reform in this area is vital. Throughout the development of these bills, the government has shown a willingness to seek reasonable compromise and bipartisan support.

Minister Peter Reith and I met directly with groups of administrative service officers around the country. We negotiated for many hours with public sector unions, agreeing to more than 30 changes to the original proposals. I then introduced amendments in parliament to take account of each one of the 20 unanimous recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts.It is disappointing, but not surprising, that many of the Labor amendments are at odds with the Public Service reforms promised by Labor in 1995. Kim Beazley, when Minister for Finance, foreshadowed:

. . . the Australian Public Service will be integrated into . . . the broader Australian community . . . Commercialisation of government activities will continue. Competition will become a commonplace, in some cases through privatisation . . .

The Labor minister, Gary Johns, urged that the APS `be placed on a similar footing to the private sector' and `proposed that secretaries and agency heads be given employment powers in their own rights'. The Labor Party when in government recognised that unrestricted appeal rights were a major barrier to performance. Minister John Dawkins an nounced in May 1984 that there would be no promotion appeals for the Senior Executive Service. Similarly, in October 1986 Minister Ralph Willis removed promotion appeal rights for senior officers, arguing:
. . . it is not appropriate for an external body . . . to be substituting its view for that of departmental management as to who is best suited to do the job.

Yet Senator Faulkner, through his actions, now seeks to introduce such appeal rights. He also suggests that his party would only be willing to support regulations providing for Australian workplace agreements in the APS for certain categories of employment in certain circumstances.

The government is not going to have its Australian Public Service employment arrangements subject to the fickle moods of the opposition and minor parties in the Senate. The ALP has introduced more than 50 amendments in the Senate. Together they would return the APS to the past, burying employment actions in layers of unnecessary prescription. The Senate's actions have prevented the government from placing the values, standards and conduct necessary for an apolitical and impartial Australian Public Service on a statutory basis for the first time.

The government is now unable to remove age discrimination, protect Public Service whistleblowers, provide a separate and independent parliamentary service or place limitations on ministerial involvement in employment decisions. This is unfortunate. But it will not weaken the government's resolve, nor will we slacken the pace of Public Service reform.

The devolution of management decision making is already being achieved under the Workplace Relations Act. The process of reform is now to be accelerated. All secretaries will be expected to finalise Australian workplace agreements with their senior executives in the near future, and the majority of secretaries will have concluded making certified agreements with their staff by the middle of next year. At the same time, the government will now proceed administratively with a number of the proposed legislative reforms. I have today instructed the Public Service Commissioner to issue directions to all agency heads to set in place many of the initiatives required for a modern Public Service.

Of course I am disappointed for those many public servants who had eagerly anticipated legislative reform. I well understand their frustrations at working under an act which is 75 years old and has had to be patched up more than 100 times. I assure them that the government will not waiver in its commitment to reform. The Australian Public Service is a great institution which the government of the day holds on trust. The coalition government is determined to do all that it can to ensure that it is handed on in a better shape to future governments. It is precisely for that reason that the government will not agree to amendments. It is now up to the Labor Party to seek common ground.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Here we have another fine mess that the government has created. What we have here with the Public Service Bill 1997 is another case of political posturing without focus on the desired public policy outcome but trying to set in place a political outcome—another double dissolution trigger—when in fact, notwithstanding there are lots of amendments with which we disagree, there are lots of reforms in this bill for which there is bipartisan support and with which, even in the form in which the bill passed through the Senate, we could have made a substantial number of agreed changes to the Public Service Act. Then, of course, we could have had a subsequent debate about the matters with which we disagree. I regard them as important and we regard them as important—that is why we made that clear in the debate here in the House and that is why we pursued them in some detail in the Senate.

SPEECH.PARA: Any government that really thinks—as the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service (Dr Kemp) pretends he thinks—that it is very important that we start to make some changes to the 1922 Public Service Act would in fact implement those agreed changes and proceed with the debate about the others. But no, what we want is a bit of a debate about a double dissolution trigger. We want to build up a bit of a back log. We want to have a series of bills to legitimise tomorrow's stunt about double dissolution triggers so the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) can come in here and grandstand to his heart's content—not tonight, when we actually could do it, but tomorrow morning so that maybe the publicity will be a bit better. And we will not do it with that bill but with this bill and the unfair dismissal bill, the other triggers they are trying to build up.

This is not about outcomes; it is about political posturing. It is not good policy. It is an absolute disgrace to pretend that you are doing this in the interests of developing a strong public service.

For this government—of any government since Federation—to pretend that it is coming in here because its commitment is to public service, and to a strong, efficient public service, is the height of hypocrisy, Mr Deputy Speaker. It is absolutely breathtaking—and there are 22,000 sacked public servants who can testify to that. They talk often about people leaving the Public Service but, for those 22,000 Australians, the Public Service left them—and it left them in the lurch. And then the government says, `We are really about a strong public service, a coherent public service, except for those 22,000 and the others in the agencies'—I am talking here about mainstream public servants—when in fact what they are doing is tearing apart the great tradition of a career public service.

We are heading towards more differentiation and dissipating the cohesion, which will make change and restructuring more difficult because you will easily create a series of fiefdoms around the Public Service run by powerful agency heads who will be individually accountable only to their ministers and to whom individual public servants will be accountable. It is bad public service policy; it is against the long‐term interests of this country; it is particularly against the long‐term interests of those Australians in greatest need who most depend upon a strong, efficient, effective Public Service capable of delivering good policy and the efficient delivery of the services that flow from that good policy. It is against the interests of the employees.

BREAK.PARA: My most profound concern with this bill is that the government's industrial relations agenda has got in the way of its public service agenda. Anything that pretends any longer that this is a bill about making the Public Service better is destroyed as soon as you analyse the fact that what it is really about is imposing the government's industrial relations agenda on public servants because they cannot get any sensible people in the private sector to take it up. This is bad for the Public Service; it is bad for Australians who depend upon the Public Service, and we will not agree with it. (Time expired)
