SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs;Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

TALKER.NAME: Dr KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the bill be laid aside.

As I indicated in my remarks a few moments ago, the government is not prepared to agree to the amendments made by the Senate which will take the Australian Public Service backwards. The opposition and Democrat senators who spoke in the Senate debate have indicated that they support reforms to remove the restrictions that bind the Public Service in red tape and which prevent it from operating efficiently, yet in the rhetoric that the various speakers used, and in the proposals that they have made, I have not found the slightest indication that they either understood the need for reform or appreciated what the nature of those reforms should be.

I have to say it was very disappointing to hear the empty and hypocritical rhetoric from the member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) just a few moments ago. It is quite clear that the Labor Party has not the slightest intention of debating the Public Service Bill with any element of seriousness. We simply heard quite false suggestions made about the government's attitude towards the Public Service.

TALK.START.PARA: —Go and ask the 22,000.
—Between 1988 and 1995 the Australian Labor Party government reduced the size of the Public Service by about 40,000.
—How many?

—By 40,000. All this shows is just how empty and misconceived your rhetoric is. The changes that the Senate has made to the bill reflect a political process which has caused so much difficulty for this country, because it is a process in which there is a surrender to narrow sectional interests. The Labor Party is the voice of those narrow sectional interests. It has put their interests above the public interests, and it is seeking to place itself as an obstacle in the pathway of proper and appropriate reform to the Public Service. In some cases, reforms which the Labor Party itself supported in office it has now attempted to reverse in the Senate. And it is that empty opportunism, it is that shallow political attitude to this legislation which is so deeply disappointing to those who have committed themselves to a very substantial and major reform which will improve conditions for members of the Public Service and improve service to the wider Australian community.

SPEECH.PARA: The amendments in the Senate do no more than attempt to reintroduce the rigidities and inefficiencies that lie at the heart of the problems being faced by the Australian Public Service. They focus on process, not on outcomes; they look to the past and not to the future. The opposition and the Democrats seek to regulate and proscribe, to control from the centre, and to ensure that whatever flexibilities the government is attempting to provide to agency heads and their employees are removed or thwarted. They seek rigid, mandated service‐wide processes that do not provide the capacity for public servants to tailor their operations to the work they perform or the needs of the clients they serve.

Let us look at the amendments that the Senate has proposed. The Senate amendments with which the government has most difficulty are those which prevent secretaries and agency heads from entering into an Australian workplace agreement—an AWA—with their employees unless the AWA covers a particular category of APS employees which has been exempted from this provision by a regulation under the Public Service Act.

The government does not support these amendments because they attempt to override the provisions of the Workplace Relations Act 1996 and place the APS on a different footing to the private sector. There is also a lack of clarity as to the operation of the clause. Other Senate amendments attempt to establish the primacy of awards and certified agreements over classification rules and determinations. The government does not accept the amendments because they are largely unnecessary or may be handled in other ways. To the extent that awards may cover matters contained in the classification rules, an award would override any rule that sought to diminish the provision in the award.

The Department of Workplace Relations and Small Business will be making regulations under the Workplace Relations Act allowing agreements to displace agency head determinations to the extent of any inconsistency. With respect to determinations made by the public service minister, it is the intention that a special ministerial determination should be able to override agreements made under the Workplace Relations Act in the interests of the APS as a whole.

The Senate has also sought to omit the provisions that the termination of employment provisions of the Workplace Relations Act will not apply to the termination of an SES employee, a secretary to a department or the head of an executive agency. The government does not accept these amendments because they treat these employees differently from their equivalents in the private sector and their counterparts in other public sectors in Australia.

Another major concern for the government are those Senate amendments which attempt to establish the merit protection commissioner as an independent statutory agency and retain and expand the current tripartite appeals process. The government does not accept these amendments because they impose binding decisions on agency heads and unduly constrain their employment powers. The amendments would also indirectly continue the costly focus on process within agencies. Furthermore, there are significant technical problems in the proposed amendments.

Further Senate amendments propose to move the definition of merit from clause 10, where it relates directly to the APS values, to clause 7, which sets out the definitions in the act. The amendments also change the definition, including the requirement for merit to be the sole consideration in a selection process rather than the primary consideration. The government does not accept these amendments. The original clause 10 provides a more workable definition than the Senate definition. The new reference to the sole consideration is more restrictive and may raise issues as to how this requirement interacts with other legislation and processes affecting employment decisions.

The government also has significant concerns with those Senate amendments which attempt to limit the powers of agency heads to engage persons as employees on other than a permanent basis and to transfer employees to other duties and locations. The government does not accept the amendments because they unnecessarily restrict the flexibility of agency heads to employ staff efficiently and economically to meet the needs of their agencies from time to time. There are also significant technical problems in relation to the application of the proposed provisions. Of a similarly limiting nature are those Senate amendments which place restrictions on the powers of agency heads to terminate employees. The government does not accept these amendments because they unnecessarily limit the exercise of termination powers and would contribute to the current emphasis on process.

The amendments, although presumably they seek to be comprehensive, preclude termination for other necessary reasons such as abandonment of employment or failure to complete a training course. They would also result in confusion in relation to the interaction of the grounds specified in the bill with those in the Workplace Relations Act. The Workplace Relations Act already protects employees by prohibiting termination on a number of grounds and by setting out procedural requirements as well as conciliation procedures and remedies.

BREAK.PARA: Another group of Senate amendments attempts to expand the coverage of the APS values and to require the Public Service Commissioner to issue directions in relation to each of the values rather than those which the commissioner deems appropriate. The government does not accept these amendments as the expansion of the values is unnecessary and confusing and because of the vagueness and lack of clarity in the proposed amendments.

Furthermore, the insertion of new subclause (j)(ii) is at odds with long established principles of remunerating APS employees and, because of its narrowness, would be at odds with Australian Industrial Relations Commission principles on wage fixation. With regard to the issue of directions, the commissioner should not have his or her functions unduly prescribed but should have the flexibility to decide when the issue of directions is appropriate.

A further group of amendments proposes to vary the provisions relating to breaches of the code of conduct, making them more prescriptive and less flexible. The government does not support these amendments because they unnecessarily restrict the flexibility of agency heads in dealing with breaches of the code of conduct and create technical problems with respect to their application. The Senate has also sought to prescribe the matters on which the Public Service Commissioner may issue directions in relation to SES employees and require certification by the commissioner prior to termination. The government does not accept the amendments, which propose unnecessary process in the legislation. The amendments are also unclear in their operation.

Further, Senate amendments require annual reports prepared by the Public Service Commissioner, secretaries to departments and the heads of executive agencies to be prepared in accordance with guidelines approved by the Joint Committee of Public Accounts and Audit on behalf of the parliament. The government does not accept the amendments as they are unnecessarily prescriptive and hinder the intended flexibility in relation to the submission of annual reports to the parlia ment, which is aimed at assisting a better alignment of key accountability and reporting mechanisms in respect of APS agencies.

The Senate has sought to require that the remuneration of the Public Service Commissioner, secretaries to departments and the heads of executive agencies—remuneration is to be determined by the Prime Minister or the agency minister, as the case may be—be set on the advice of the Remuneration Tribunal and published in the Gazette. The government does not accept these amendments, because they are unnecessarily prescriptive. In practice the Remuneration Tribunal would be consulted and the remuneration range published in annual reports. The Senate has also sought to prescribe in greater detail the responsibilities of secretaries to departments. The government does not accept the amendment, because it is unnecessarily prescriptive and is uncertain in its operation.

Further Senate amendments relate to the establishment of executive agencies and the responsibilities, appointment and termination of heads of executive agencies. The amendments insert accountability requirements for executive agencies; prescribe in greater detail the responsibilities of heads of executive agencies, similar to the amendment in relation to secretaries to departments; and require the involvement of the secretary to the Prime Minister's department in the appointment and termination of the heads of executive agencies, rather than the relevant secretary, and the additional involvement of the Public Service Commissioner in a termination. The government does not accept these amendments as they are unnecessarily prescriptive. The accountability requirements in particular raise significant issues about the proposed operation of this amendment.

A further Senate amendment proposes the omission of subclause 72(3), which specifies that the termination of employment provisions in the Workplace Relations Act do not apply to terminations of employees of agencies affected by machinery of government changes. The government does not accept this amendment as the removal of this subclause would potentially allow employees transferred under this clause access to the unlawful termination provisions of the Workplace Relations Act, even though their employment continues by virtue of the operation of subclauses 72(1)(b) or (c).

The protections afforded by the Workplace Relations Act against unlawful termination are not justified in these circumstances as the termination is of a largely technical nature. Proposed replacement clause 72(3) would reduce the flexibility available under the Workplace Relations Act for both APS and non‐APS agencies to reach agreement with employees regarding the terms and conditions of employment for staff transferred to their agency.

The government is also concerned with the proposed amendment which prevents the delegation of a power or function to a person who is not an APS employee or a statutory officer unless the Public Service Commissioner approves in writing the proposed delegation. The government does not accept this amendment, because it would cause considerable administrative inconvenience in requiring the commissioner's approval for such situations as Defence Force personnel, persons on secondment from other public services or contractors who may supervise APS employees.

The Senate has proposed the insertion of an additional object in the act which the government requires or regards as quite unnecessary. The Senate has also inserted provisions for the recovery of additional remuneration from agency heads, the Public Service Commissioner and the Merit Protection Commissioner. The government does not accept this amendment because it adds unnecessary detail and prescription to the act.

Mr Deputy Speaker Reid, I am sure you will have noted and members will have noted that the most frequent verbs and nouns in this speech have been `prescribe' and `prescription'. That reflects the nature of the amendments proposed by the Senate. The common theme of these amendments is that they add unnecessary and ambiguous detail to the act and, through a culture of central control, seek to inhibit the ability of agency heads to manage their agencies efficiently and effectively for the benefit of their employees and of the Australian people. The amendments look back fondly to a Public Service governed by rules and regulations.

These amendments will be deeply disappointing to members of the Public Service who have worked so hard to achieve reforms. I know they will be deeply disappointing to members of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, such as the member for Kooyong (Mr Georgiou) who has worked so hard to put together a bill which could be acceptable to both sides of politics. They reflect the fact that the Labor Party has regrettably in this area—as in so many other areas in opposition as in government, but it is even more noticeable in opposition—made itself the mouthpiece for the relevant union. What we have here is the Labor Party walking away from its own reforms. It is now walking away from matters that it stood firmly on behalf of in government and matters which it championed in government.

Members of the public will ask themselves, `What does this tell us about the Australian Labor Party?' What it tells us is that the Labor Party is a party which is prepared to play shallow and shabby politics with one of the most important institutions in this country. It is a party which has no guiding principles. It is a party which is purely prepared to take shallow decisions without any vision for the future. It stands for nothing. It is the mouthpiece, the voice, of sectional interests, and that is deeply regrettable.

Throughout this whole process the government has shown that it is prepared to work towards a compromise piece of legislation that will provide a framework for the present government and alternative governments. The Labor Party has not been prepared to accept this process. I deeply regret that. I believe that the detailed rebuttal that I have just provided of the amendments that have been made by the Senate give the lie to the claim by the member for Canberra that the government is simply seeking to politically posture in relation to this piece of legislation. Our objections to these amendments are substantial. That is why the government proposes that the bill now be set aside.

TALK.START.PARA: —Wasn't that a sad spectacle? If you drag away the abuse and take away the ideological fervour, you actually have a speech that could have been delivered in about 45 seconds. It was a very sad spectacle of someone who has made a predetermined position and then sets out after the event to set up a series of explanations as to why they might have made the decision, because otherwise you could not have come to the conclusions on the basis of the arguments put. It was most hysterically clear at the end when the minister said, `We've tried very hard to compromise. We have sought to get an agreement.' I thought, `I'd better go back and check.' I thought we were debating the fact that the government has just rejected all the amendments. I thought, `Where's the compromise? Which of the alternative views are they accommodating?' There are no amendments being accepted, Mr Deputy Speaker—none.
—Have you forgotten the report of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts?
—No, I have not. I congratulated the committee in my previous speech—
—Selective memory.
—A very selective memory.

—I congratulated the committee when I spoke in the second reading debate, and my colleague Senator Faulkner also congratulated the Joint Committee of Public Accounts' recommendations and the fact that the committee did contribute to an improvement in the bill. I would have preferred the committee went beyond some of the things it did, but I congratulated it in my speech in the second reading debate. As I said, my colleague the shadow minister responsible for the Public Service, who participated in that committee, did the same in his contribution in the Senate, and it is a better bill for that. But it is not the normal orthodox English language definition of compromise to say, `Fifty noes and no yeses is a reasonable compromise position.' It is, I suppose, the fairly orthodox definition of this minister's view of compromise, but of nobody else in Australia.

BREAK.PARA: We did have a bit of an argument and we almost, Mr Deputy Speaker, got a little unruly, to your surprise and chagrin, I am sure, about the discussion concerning cuts to the Public Service. Nobody could deny that the previous government over 13 years made some tough decisions about the Public Service, and those of us who are members of parliament representing the ACT had to deal with those and we spoke to our constituents about it. I am happy to say they continued to vote for us, but I do not pretend that they enjoyed all of those decisions. They did not. They were critical of some.

But you cannot say that those things took place and that is an indication that we are similarly approaching this matter, when we had a reduction of over 40,000 in seven or eight years. On top of that, the coalition promised at the election that there would be only 2,500 Public Service jobs lost over three years. I said at the time that I thought there was a nought missing, and I was attacked by my opponent and others during the election that mine was an outrageous proposition. Once again, I am happy to say the good citizens of Canberra were wise enough to see through their ridiculous assertions.

What we have found is that I was actually too modest; there was more than a nought missing. We have had more than 10 times the number of jobs lost in half the period. The rate has been 20 times that which the government said it would be at the election. It was double the rate that was occurring at the height of the previous government's tough decisions about the Public Service and building over and above all the decisions that were previously made—not in place of them, but over and above them. So let us just put that in some sort of perspective.

One thing that did become clear in the minister's so‐called detailed rebuttal was that this is very much a bill about an industrial relations agenda in addition to some Public Service agenda. The opposition agrees with some of that, as is evident from the fact that some parts of the bill have not been amended. There were some matters out of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts with which we all agreed. So there are some matters of Public Service reform we could deal with on a bipartisan basis if the government wished to, but they do not.

A substantial amount of this bill is about changing the way in which industrial relations operates in the Public Service and not in a way that is likely to leave the Public Service better placed to serve the Australian people. It is simply using it as the advance guard for industrial relations changes the government would like to make and would like to see applying more widely but cannot get sensible employers and employees to agree to in the private sector. So they are seeking to use the Public Service as the advance guard.

That has been done before. It was done a long time ago by a previous Labor government and, while I agreed with a number of the individual things they did, the consequences were not good. All I could say at the time is, `I told you so.' They listened as little then as some people did later, perhaps about as much as this minister will tonight. That is not a strategy which I recommend and it is an analogy which is becoming more and more apt.

In reasonable consideration of the time—the time pressures on the House and the 10 minutes I have—I cannot possibly deal with all the amendments and the detailed rebuttal that the minister gave. It would, anyway, be quite pointless. It is appropriate for the government to put its point of view about all the amendments on the table because that is why it has moved the motion. All of them require detailed consideration either when it is reconsidered here in the consideration in detail stage or if and when it goes back to the Senate. But I did want to deal with some of the amendments because they go to some of the principles.

One is the question of unfair dismissals. We have had a lot of debate in this place about unfair dismissals. I am happy to say the most outrageous debate about unfair dismissals occurred prior to the last election and I did not have to put up with it. But there has been quite a fair bit of debate in the period since March 1996. One of the things the government said was that its changes instituted a fair go all round; that this set of provisions was reasonable to both sides of the employment contract. Ironically, it is not a fair go that goes all the way round to the government's own employees, only to some of them. We do not think that is a fair, reasonable or appropriate way for the Commonwealth to deal with its own employees and we will continue not to support that. If the unfair dismissal provisions are to remain as they are, they ought to apply to the Commonwealth's employees across the board.

It is not the time to go to great lengths, but I am very concerned about the proposal that—if I can paraphrase—the merit protection operations of the Commonwealth Public Service should in effect become an advisory function, should be like the Ombudsman, and provide a view to which people can say, `That is very interesting. I intend to take no notice.' That seems to me to be a profound problem. There is a lot more detail in it that one would want to talk about and we will talk about it in the consideration in detail stage here subsequently or in the Senate subsequently, but I am very concerned about that. I regard it as almost a derisory proposal.

We had a commentary about the definition of `merit'. I realise it is not easy, but the proposal in the opposition's amendments sounded pretty extraordinary and I thought I must have forgotten what it was, so I went back and checked. We are saying that merit is—and I quote only in part—`based on the relationship between an applicant's work‐related qualities and the work‐related qualities identified by the Agency as required for the job'. What an extraordinary definition. It is obviously very unreasonable that nobody should ever consider that merit should deal with the relationship between the qualities an individual has and the qualities identified as required for the job—in other words, excluding those matters that do not relate to the job requirements. That is the definition.

The definition does not seem unreasonable. If we were looking for an agreed basis on which we might go forward, certainly I think we can proceed from a basis something like that. Maybe the government would want to come back with a further slight modification. We will see what they are proposing. But the flat rejection does not give us much prospect of reasonable agreement. We did have a mantra that was obvious and that the minister referred to is in his final remarks just before he flipped out in the last few paragraphs.

When the minister was talking about consistent themes, he talked about how it was prescriptive. The counterpoint to that was his continued emphasis on the word `flexibility'. Flexibility is, in certain things, such as gymnastics, a very desirable characteristic. But in many aspects of the law, `flexibility' is code for enabling those who are powerful to use their power with less constraint. It is particularly so in the employment relationship. It has been code very often in the debate around the Workplace Relations Act. `Flexibility' is code for taking away the restraints upon the capacity of the more powerful party to the agreement to exercise their power.

TALK.START.PARA: —You mean the unions, do you?

—Where they are the more powerful, that might be a cause for concern. I do not think that is where we are seeing people suffering from this heightened flexibility around Australia. Notwithstanding the phobias of the member for La Trobe (Mr Charles), I do not think that is what most Australians think is the cause for greatest concern. The member for La Trobe should just keep drinking his water. We have a very serious problem here.
—I don't think you meant the implication in that, did you?

—Yes. We have a concern that the government is expressing a profound concern, trying to elevate as a matter of principle the fact that the remuneration outcomes might need to be published. What a shocking suggestion: they might be public. The financial arrangements made for the higher echelons of the Public Service might have to be published. Requirements suggest that about executive agencies. Once again, I thought they had seemed reasonably modest, when we formulated them. The way the minister described them, I thought they must have been changed in the course of the debate. They must have said something other than that which I recalled. The relevant paragraph of the proposed new clause 66 says:

BREAK.PARA: The Head of an Executive Agency has a duty to assist the Agency Minister to fulfil his or her accountability obligations to the Parliament by providing full and accurate information to the Parliament about the factual and technical background to policies and their administration.

I suppose there must be hidden deep in there somewhere some profound meaning for why that is a cause of such shock to the government. It seems a very orthodox definition of accountability requirements to the parliament.

In summing up, I notice that the minister suggested that the opposition's amendments were deeply disappointing to public servants. I have to say that I probably represent in this parliament more public servants than anybody else, and I have not had one express that view to me yet—not one. I have had quite a large number come through to my office each day. I have constituency operations. At every social function I attend, there are usually a few public servants there. They are not all Labor voters, of course—I am happy that two‐thirds of them are, but not all of them are—but I have not yet had one express that view. I have had quite a few express concerns about the government's bill and most of them say, `Yes, it is improved by the consideration of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts,' and I agree with that. But in all this time I have not yet had one come in and say, `I am deeply,' or even slightly `disappointed by the opposition's approach on this matter.' Everybody who has discussed it with us has said that they think what we are doing is preferable to what you are doing. Some of them would like other changes, but I have not found one who agrees with your view. (Time expired)
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs and Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate amendments be disagreed to.

The Senate also moved three amendments to the Public Employment (Consequential and Transitional) Amendment Bill 1997 . These amendments were also unacceptable to the government. Of most concern is the amendment which seeks to retain the complex, outdated and inflexible mobility provisions of the current Public Service Act for those employees who currently have rights under those provisions.

These rights impose heavy management costs in terms of the contingent liabilities represented by return rights for more than 50,000 people. The government was prepared to allow a transitional period under which these employees could return to the APS. What it is not prepared to do is to continue these rights indefinitely.

A further amendment extends the period from 12 months to three years during which agencies can amend or revoke the existing service‐wide determinations which translate across to individual agencies before they lapse. The amendment also prevents agency heads from diminishing or revoking any determination provision unless that provision is incorporated in an award or certified agreement. The government does not accept the amendment because it is of the view that 12 months is an adequate transitional period. Moreover, the amendment would reduce the flexibility of agency heads and prevent them from rationalising existing determinations which will have no relevance to the employees of their agency.

The member for Canberra (Mr McMullan) suggests that the government has not been interested in compromise and that public servants will not be concerned over the attitudes of the Labor Party to this bill and the amendments in the Senate. Let me say that the process of consultation which the government has undertaken in the preparation and development of this bill with administrative service officers is absolutely unprecedented in the development of Public Service legislation. There has never been a process of that kind, and certainly none adopted by the Labor Party. This government has undoubtedly consulted more widely with individual public servants in relation to this legislation than the Labor Party has ever done.

In relation to the government's willingness to compromise, I simply make the point that there were 30 changes to the original draft bill before it was introduced. There were 15 hours of consultations with the trade unions. There were amendments introduced to the bill to meet all 20 recommendations of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. The government also accepted the suggestion of the committee in relation to the Merit Protection Commissioner.

BREAK.PARA: I also want to make the point that it is not the government which is confusing industrial relations reforms and concerns with Public Service reforms. Regrettably, what we see in relation to this bill is the determination of the opposition to attempt to roll back the effects of the Workplace Relations Act, which has already been passed by the parliament and which is currently being applied within the Public Service. The simple fact is that, for ideological reasons and because it is the sectional voice of the trade union movement, the opposition is using this important piece of legislation to conduct a rearguard action against the decision of the parliament to pass the Workplace Relations Act.

I am afraid that it ill becomes the shadow minister, the member for Canberra, to suggest that the government has lost focus in this area. The Labor Party should accept the decision of the parliament; it should recognise that the Public Service is already operating with provisions of the workplace relations legislation and doing so most effectively. I urge the opposition, if there are discussions at a future time about this legislation when it is reintroduced into the parliament, to keep in mind that there are many people in the Public Service who would like it to get off its traditional hobbyhorse, to get the public interest firmly in focus and to support this outstanding piece of legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief in response to this. This is the transitional and consequential bill and the arguments with regard to it are essentially those which you have already traversed, and I do not wish to waste anybody's time about that. I will simply respond by saying that the opposition does have strong opposition to many aspects of what is now the Workplace Relations Act. We do recognise it is the law of the country, and we do have a strategy to do something about it, and after the next election we will do it.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate provides an opportunity to speak on the appropriation bills, an opportunity to take stock of the current economic climate in Australia and an opportunity to look at the government's strategies and implementation of policies and the positive impact these strategies and policies have on an electorate such as Bendigo and the nation as a whole.

SPEECH.PARA: I just want to quote some figures to the House. The Australian economy has grown at an annualised rate of almost six per cent for the September quarter and there is talk of strong expansion for several more quarters. For the month of July, department stores reached their biggest monthly increase in sales on record. For the September quarter, retail sales in this country were at a record for the 15‐year history of the Australian Bureau of Statistics. We are told that lending for the construction of new homes grew by almost eight per cent in the month of September. Sales of motor vehicles and trucks will reach over $700,000 for the first time ever in this country.

Other surveys tell us that business conditions are the best they have been for more than two years. Business investment is forecast to increase by eight per cent this financial year. TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to concentrate on the additional estimates for the Department of Veterans' Affairs. I note that the department is seeking an increase in appropriated funds of over $300 million, which represents a nearly five per cent increase in the budget estimate for the department. Whilst the portfolio additional estimates detail some 20 pages of extra appropriations, it is notable that an extra $245 million is sought for one single appropriation item, namely, the maintenance of patients in non‐departmental institutions under the health care and service subprogram. This budget item was allocated some $826 million, so the additional appropriation sought by the minister involves a 30 per cent increase.

SPEECH.PARA: I would be guilty of a massive understatement if I said that this was only a minor variation. It is amazing to note that the additional estimates statement devotes less than 30 words to explaining this massive additional spending now anticipated. Two less than informative explanations are given. One element of the $245 million increase in the appropriation to maintain veterans in non‐departmental institutions is that in the portfolio additional estimates statement it is indicated that an extra $189 million is required by DVA because of the transfer from health and community services of the payment of residential care subsidies to entitled veterans. This is a bookkeeping change that is part of the government's regressive changes to residential aged care funding.

As has become painfully clear over the past few weeks, with the solitary exception of ex‐prisoners of war, veterans and war widows are as much affected as other senior citizens by the coalition's up‐front nursing home entry fees, and its new system for nursing homes and hostels. No‐one would begrudge the fact that ex‐POWs have their resident contribution paid for them by DVA. This welcome measure was an initiative of the former Labor government that was introduced at the urging of my predecessor, the Hon. Tom Uren, who was himself an ex‐POW. I note that the department's annual report indicates that 267 ex‐POWs living in nursing homes are benefiting from this measure. Whilst this is commendable, 267 veterans are a very small minority of our ex‐service personnel and the war widows. For many weeks, I have been calling on the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Bruce Scott) to stand up for the thousands of other veterans and war widows who face the threat of paying up‐front entry fees and high weekly fees under the coalition's aged care changes. He has constantly failed to do so, and appears content to leave the matter to the Minister for Family Services (Mr Warwick Smith).

Unfortunately, veterans cannot expect any benefit from the extra $189 million which is being appropriated for residential aged care under these bills. According to advice to the Senate additional estimates hearing, this is merely a bookkeeping change. From 1 October, the government has determined that the payment of residential care subsidies for veterans and war widows who have gold or white treatment cards will be the responsibility of the Department of Veterans' Affairs. Previously, most of these subsidies were payable by health and community services. So what we see in these bills is an extra $189 million being charged against the Veterans Affairs' budget. But it is not really extra money, and it goes to the service provider and not to veterans. At the same time, we see a minister who has so far failed to get one extra cent to exempt veterans and war widows from the coalition's changes to nursing homes and hostels.

As a result, veterans and war widows who enter nursing homes now face paying an additional entry charge of up to $4,380. This charge is on top of the standard resident contribution and is to be imposed on veterans with total assets, including the family home, of more than $22,500.

None of this is about the ageing of the population or about improving the quality of care provided by nursing homes. It is all about the coalition's ideological commitment to user pays and a reduced role for government as an incentive for self‐provision, as exemplified by the claim by its National Commission of Audit that:

. . . a high proportion of our retired population are in a position to meet at least a significant share of the costs of their own health and care needs. The Commission is not questioning the policy objective of providing nursing home assistance to those in need but is questioning whether the preservation of clients' wealth, at the expense of the rest of the community, should be part of that policy objective. More importantly, a large share of those currently working have the potential to prepare for their future health and care needs but face a substantial disincentive through current government funding arrangements.
There we have the genesis, the ideological bent and the driving force behind these measures.

I would seek clarification from the minister as to what measures he will implement to spell out to the ex‐service community the details of the aged care changes that so severely impact on them. In the September issue of Vetaffairs there were a full two pages of government propaganda with ludicrous, almost laughable, headings, such as `Bonds to lift accommodation standards in nursing homes' and a further article `Looking after the veteran community'. This was all before the Prime Minister's famous `I was wrong' backdown. It was notable that the October‐November issue of Vetaffairs wisely chose to ignore the aged care changes completely, presumably because no‐one could tell them what the government's policy actually was.
Now we see the Minister for Health and Family Services (Dr Wooldridge) has written to the Prime Minister saying:

It will be vital to avoid reigniting the issue in the media. Accordingly, I propose not to make a formal Ministerial Statement to the House nor any other highly visible public announcement in relation to the technical details of the policy . . . Instead I propose to have the Department of Health and Family Services issue fact sheets and information products clarifying issues as necessary . . .
This is an appallingly cynical approach to the community's right to know the details of a major government program; one that has generated considerable controversy and uncertainty in the community.

BREAK.PARA: The other aspect of these budget changes comes under the title of `Cost of veterans' usage of non‐departmental hospitals'. This is now expected to be more than $56.2 million higher than the budget estimate. Through questioning by Labor senators at the additional estimates hearing on 13 November, the government revealed that an extra $9.5 million was due to the sale of Lady Davidson Hospital and $5.7 million was due to greater than expected usage of public hospitals. By implication, this means that $41 million was due to increased usage of private hospitals.

Previously, Lady Davidson Hospital was funded under a number of separate appropriate items. Variations in these items have to be reported as part of the additional estimates process, thus providing the parliament—that is, the people of Australia—with at least some hazy insight into the financial transactions. Until recently, the only information on the public record about this sale was the minister's release of 26 June announcing that the hospital had been sold to Australian Hospital Care with effect from 1 October, and indicating that there would be a Mirvac housing project and a RAAF Association aged care facility developed on vacant parts of the site. No financial information was provided, and my office was then informed that the details of the service contract between the department and the new owners was commercially confidential information.

Subsequently, we learnt in the department's annual report that the government received $16.5 million for the sale of the hospital and that a parcel of land worth a further $5.8 million had been transferred to Australian Estate Management. What is more interesting are the further revelations in the additional estimates statement. As Lady Davidson ceased to be a federally managed facility on 1 October, some $4.2 million that was previously allocated is now no longer required. This is to be offset against the additional amount of $9.5 million that I have already referred to which is to enable the department, under a separate appropriation item, to contract for Australian Hospital Care to provide care for veterans for the remainder of the financial year. The fact that there is a $5.3 million variation between the two figures raises some interesting issues. One possible explanation is that the government has contracted out the running of the hospital to the private sector to increase the cost to the taxpayer compared with what applied when it was run directly by the government.

I would not be surprised if this was the correct interpretation. But the government hides behind the confidentiality of commercial transactions to prevent the parliament—that is, the people—ascertaining the truth. A further possible explanation is that the sale took effect from a different date than was anticipated when the budget was finalised. This could well be part of the story, but I do not see how an adjustment to the date could itself produce such a substantial variation in the outlays involved.

According to the Australian of 16 October, the department is probably the largest purchaser of private hospital services in Australia and, seemingly, the minister supports a mindless increased reliance on private hospitals. Thus I am becoming increasingly concerned that we are being asked to appropriate ever increasing amounts of taxpayer funds to private hospital operators without being fully provided with the necessary information. I stress that in raising this issue I am not pursuing an agenda against the new owners and operators of Lady Davidson Hospital. They operate 17 other hospitals in Australia and I am sure they are dedicated to providing a high‐class service to veterans.

I would also like to highlight the minister's complete and utter silence on the future of Victoria's specialist repatriation hospital, which is now part of the Austin and Repatriation Medical Centre, A&RMC. This hospital has clearly suffered under the destructive policies of the Kennett government. Members do not need to take my word for this. They only have to read the annual report of the minister's own National Treatment Monitoring Committee. It stated:

Although hospital data presented by the Department during the year indicated good usage of the facilities on both campuses, a continuing drift of patients away from A&RMC was evident . . . Members raised a number of concerns during the year about the A&RMC, relating mainly to access to the Heidelberg campus and long waits during emergency after‐hours admissions.

The accompanying report of the Victorian Treatment Monitoring Committee contained more specific details. It revealed that the number of veteran separations from the hospital had fallen to around 9,000, which is 45 per cent less than the number that occurred when the Commonwealth last ran the hospital. I would suggest that a 45 per cent fall in veteran usage of the hospital is more than the drift referred to in the annual report. A full scale evacuation would seem a more appropriate description.

Part of the fall could be explained by veterans choosing to access hospitals closer to their home. However, I find it hard to believe that this is the only factor involved and very much doubt that any other repatriation hospital has seen such a fall in veteran usage. In reality, veterans are voting with their feet against the Kennett government's management of the hospital.

I note that in the Herald‐Sun of 6 June staff claimed the hospital's operating theatre walls were now washed only once a month—previously this was a task undertaken daily before Kennett's cuts—and that services and staff conditions were at risk because of the coalition's contracting‐out agenda. In this context there has been total inaction and total silence from the minister, as has been detailed earlier, in regard to aged care and nursing care in this country.

In my speech the other night I started to quote the Hon. Bill Hayden in relation to a letter he wrote in his position as the chief negotiator with the Right to Negotiate Team in respect of the Century Zinc mineral project. I will table the letter in due course, but I want to go through some of the quotes here. I will quote parts of the letter, not because I want to selectively quote it but because it is a very long letter which I note was sent to the state opposition leader Mr Beattie; the Prime Minister, Mr Howard; the Deputy Prime Minister, Mr Tim Fischer; the federal opposition leader, Mr Beazley; and the Democrats leader, Senator Cheryl Kernot before she jumped. Mr Hayden obviously believed it was important enough to write to all those people. The letter states:
What became abundantly clear to me quite early is how complex, even confusing, the drafting of the relevant legislation is—
that is the Native Title Act, I hasten to add, not the legislation that has just been rejected by the Senate—

the opportunities the legislation offers for outside manipulation of processes and for the adoption of measures which come perilously close at times to being extortion; the absence of any definition of who can be a claimant and the seemingly unlimited opportunities for people to register as such; the unrepresentativeness of some who register as claimants; the confusion and tensions which can become rampant as long standing factional and family disputes within a tribal group manifest themselves at the expense of the issue to be settled; the jealousy and mistrust which can arise between different tribal bodies and which can impair negotiating processes. And this is by no means an exhaustive list of the problems which stud the present NTA.
The letter continues:

Incidentally, it is as clear as a pike staff that the Keating Labor Government (and Parliament more generally) believed that it had enacted legislation with the Native Title Act which established, inter alia , that the issue of a pastoral lease extinguished any native title which might otherwise have existed. The Chief Justice of the High Court and two of his colleagues ruled in that way recently, and with a common, and I might add a good common sense judgment. A majority determination of only one (ie. four justices) ruled otherwise, for a variety of expressed reasons as between the different justices and in this prolix and unreassuring manner law was made and imposed on the community at clear odds with the quite apparent intent of the representative and accountable legislature. This surprising majority judgment will make an already difficult process for determining issues related to claims for native title even more complex, (much, much more so as things stand right now), extremely time consuming and add further to the costs of what is already a very expensive procedure.
It goes on:
I sincerely hope that the Howard Government is able to remedy these grave defects. But allowing for the nature of the Senate at times this will probably be a very difficult task.
Prophetic words, indeed. It continues:

The tragedy of failure to rectify these shortcomings will cause major national economic detriment. I doubt that many Australians realise that Australia's comparative advantages as a venue for large scale investment in mineral development projects is apparently facing stiffer competitions around the globe.
Further on it says:

I expect that I should propose some positive alternatives after expressing these criticisms of aspects of the present processes. First, the right to be a claimant should be clearly defined and limited by statute to some person or persons or a body who or which is genuinely representative.
The letter continues:

Resolution of the issue of Native Title, now that the High Court has made it a permanent part of the national social‐political‐economic landscape, is beyond me, in spite of the simplistic nostrums some have recommended. First, we do not have a clear, precise meaning to this concept, one which can be applied generally and practically. The recent High Court judgments make that clear. Every case has to be considered separately and from a fresh start. This overall process, in contested cases, will be extraordinarily complex and time consuming and could go on exhaustively and without conclusion through the lifetime of a generation of Australians. If that sounds like hyperbole look at the record of the National Native Title Tribunal. In spite of being staffed by diligent, able and committed people not one contested native title claim has been resolved by that body after four years of operation. It is, furthermore, confronted with a huge backlog of claims, many yet to be properly addressed and in all, representing, I suspect, an almost impossible task in any practical sense. And it is, because of the requirements imposed on it and the procedures which, accordingly, have to be adopted, a costly organisation to maintain. Imagine the resources which it will require for this expanded function arising from the recent Wik decision! Consider then the likely delays in adjudicating claims!

What fascinates me is that most ordinary members of the public, from my experience with them, mistakenly presume that native title is the equivalent of the right of Aboriginal entry onto leased land for traditional ceremonial and hunting purposes. It is, of course, much more than that. The best way I can describe the concept, as a simplistic and easy working guideline, is that Native Title is somewhat akin to freehold land ownership in circumstances where, for instance, the valid conditions of a pastoral lease have not extinguished that right. Costly and lengthy legal disputes will occur, of course, over whether any degree of extinguishment has taken place or not. And what a congested legal process will build up.

It is a long letter. Bill Hayden has the respect of many Australians right across a broad political spectrum. Quite frankly, for Bill Hayden, who has been involved, to express these concerns is a very clear indication that this government's decision to put up a 10‐point plan has been vindicated. It is an utter tragedy for this country that the Senate did what it did today.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the appropriation bills, I wish to make some comments on the transport appropriations, and in particular appropriations that have not been adequately explained by this government. In fact, on several occasions, we have had a refusal to explain. I refer to consultancies regarding the water front which have been awarded to a variety of people who have very good qualifications with respect to their Liberal credentials—including working in the Liberal Party secretariat and working for former Liberal ministers, former Liberal premiers and the like—but who have very little in the way of expertise on waterfront reform.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that the minister representing the then minister for transport in the Senate, Senator Alston—when refusing to table the report from one of these consultants, ACIL Economics, which is headed by David Trebeck, formerly of the National Farmers Federation and former Liberal Party operative—indicated the reason for refusing to table this report was that individuals may be under threat of physical violence if the report was tabled. He did not actually indicate which individuals would be so under threat, nor did he indicate who would potentially be threatening them. In recent days, we have become aware of some other issues associated with prospective violence in waterfront matters—not necessarily of the sort that Senator Alston had in mind but, nonetheless, equally or even more serious.

We now perhaps know what he was referring to in this issue. We have evidence that there is a group of industrial mercenaries being created to work on the Australian waterfront, headed by Mr Michael Wells and Mr Peter Kilfoyle, with expertise in areas such as: crowd control; electronic surveillance; training in small arms; close quarters personal control, including unarmed combat techniques, restraint holds and blocks, use of a baton, attack blocks and holds, use of handcuffs and various methods of searching offenders. It has been drawn to my attention this evening that, on 24 September 1987 at the Magistrates Court in Goulburn, Peter Kilfoyle was convicted of possession of a sawn‐off shotgun and for failing to stop after an accident.

I have also been advised that in September 1994, Peter Kilfoyle worked for a very brief period as a bodyguard for Victorian Premier, Jeff Kennett, while he was in Ballarat. I do not contest Mr Kilfoyle's right to work and apply the skills that he clearly has in certain circumstances. Clearly, there is a need for these sorts of skills in some situations in our community. That cannot be contested.

But what I do criticise is a situation where this government is endorsing, approving and supporting the deployment of ex‐military—and until now current military—people on the waterfront, organised by people such as Mr Kilfoyle and others of this background. It is extraordinary that the government has refused to answer so many questions. The Prime Minister (Mr Howard) has refused to answer on two occasions whether there is any government money involved in this exercise. The Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business (Mr Reith) has refused to answer, both in this chamber and outside to the media, whether his staff had any prior knowledge of this exercise.

We have a situation where probably the most serious industrial relations drama in this country's history is about to unfold over the next few months. The government is pretending that it knows nothing and pretending that it has had no involvement; yet, day by day, the indications of its complicity are mounting. It is an absolute disgrace that the Howard government is supporting a covert operation to put troops on the Australian waterfront organised by people of this background.

As I have indicated, Mr Wells and Mr Kilfoyle are entitled to work in various forms of activities, various occupations, making use of the skills and expertise that they have. But their skills and expertise are entirely inappropriate for industrial relations—be it on the waterfront or anywhere else—they are entirely inappropriate for the sort of activity that they are now engaged in, and with the overt support of the government. The government is claiming that it is not involved in organising this exercise, yet the indications are mounting that it very clearly is. The Prime Minister is refusing to answer questions that indicate whether or not that involvement is there.

However, even if we can believe that there is no involvement, even if we can believe Peter Reith when he says that he had no previous knowledge and that it does not matter if his staff did or not, this government is approving of this exercise. The Minister for Defence (Mr McLachlan) stood up yesterday and said, `Great stuff. Fantastic. If it is going to improve competition on the waterfront, I am all for it.' Those are his very words. The government, the Prime Minister and the various ministers involved have all indicated that they approve of this process.

It is a total disgrace that the federal government can approve of what is now unfolding, where you have got troops—former military and current military people—being organised in a covert operation; so covert that it involves them being locked up for three weeks in a hangar somewhere in New South Wales when they get back in order to train additional people. They are not even going to be let out in case they might frighten the locals. It is a covert operation with the involvement of a foreign government in order to use their port facilities for training purposes and in order to displace existing Australian workers who are complying with the law, who are not breaking any law or any industrial regulations, who are complying with their industrial agreements, putting them out of work and putting troops onto the waterfront.

There is a legitimate debate in this country about waterfront reform. The government has one view; the opposition has a different view. That is a legitimate debate. But, regardless of what position you take in that debate, regardless of your view as to whether the government's perspective on how good or bad the waterfront is is correct or our perspective is correct or what the appropriate approach is, this is not the answer. This is a disaster for this country. This government will live to regret its involvement in and its endorsement of this outrageous activity.

I really think, Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, that your constituents and the people of Australia would want us to consider these amendments properly. I said to the Leader of the House earlier tonight that part of my job as Deputy Manager of Opposition Business is to be a nasty piece of work, but I am also aware of the view that I had when I sat in your chair, Mr Deputy Speaker, and in the Speaker's chair, that the House of Representatives matters.
